      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Name_and_etymology">Name and etymology</span></h2> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Modern_English" title="Modern English">modern English</a> word <span id="Name"></span><span id="Etymology"></span> <i>Earth</i> developed from a wide variety of <a href="/wiki/Middle_English" title="Middle English">Middle English</a> forms,<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[n 6]</a></sup> which derived from an <a href="/wiki/Old_English" title="Old English">Old English</a> noun most often spelled <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/eor%C3%B0e" class="extiw" title="wikt:eorðe">eorðe</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-oedearth_44-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oedearth-44">[39]</a></sup> It has cognates in every <a href="/wiki/Germanic_languages" title="Germanic languages">Germanic language</a>, and their <a href="/wiki/Proto-Germanic" class="mw-redirect" title="Proto-Germanic">proto-Germanic</a> root has been reconstructed as <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:Proto-Germanic/er%C3%BE%C5%8D" class="extiw" title="wikt:Appendix:Proto-Germanic/erþ?">*<i>erþ?</i></a>. In its earliest appearances, <i>eorðe</i> was already being used to translate the many senses of <a href="/wiki/Latin_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin language">Latin</a> <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/terra" class="extiw" title="wikt:terra">terra</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient Greek language">Greek</a> <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%B3%E1%BF%86" class="extiw" title="wikt:??">??</a> (<i>g?</i>): the ground,<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[n 7]</a></sup> its <a href="/wiki/Soil" title="Soil">soil</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[n 8]</a></sup> dry land,<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[n 9]</a></sup> the human world,<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[n 10]</a></sup> the surface of the world (including the sea),<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[n 11]</a></sup> and the globe itself.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[n 12]</a></sup> As with <a href="/wiki/Terra_(goddess)" class="mw-redirect" title="Terra (goddess)">Terra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gaia_(goddess)" class="mw-redirect" title="Gaia (goddess)">Gaia</a>, Earth was a <a href="/wiki/Earth_goddess" title="Earth goddess">personified goddess</a> in <a href="/wiki/Germanic_religion_(aboriginal)" title="Germanic religion (aboriginal)">Germanic paganism</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Angles" title="Angles">Angles</a> were listed by <a href="/wiki/Tacitus" title="Tacitus">Tacitus</a> as among the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_paganism" title="Anglo-Saxon paganism">devotees</a> of <a href="/wiki/Nerthus" title="Nerthus">Nerthus</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[48]</a></sup> and later <a href="/wiki/Norse_mythology" title="Norse mythology">Norse mythology</a> included <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B6r%C3%B0" title="Jörð">Jörð</a>, a giantess often given as the mother of <a href="/wiki/Thor" title="Thor">Thor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-SIMEK179_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SIMEK179-61">[49]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Originally, <i>earth</i> was written in lowercase, and from <a href="/wiki/Early_Middle_English" class="mw-redirect" title="Early Middle English">early Middle English</a>, its <a href="/wiki/Definite" class="mw-redirect" title="Definite">definite</a> sense as "the globe" was expressed as <i><a href="/wiki/Definite_article" class="mw-redirect" title="Definite article">the</a> earth</i>. By <a href="/wiki/Early_Modern_English" title="Early Modern English">Early Modern English</a>, many nouns were capitalized, and <i>the earth</i> became (and often remained) <i>the Earth</i>, particularly when referenced along with other heavenly bodies. More recently, the name is sometimes simply given as <i>Earth</i>, by analogy with the names of the <a href="/wiki/Solar_System" title="Solar System">other planets</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-oedearth_44-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oedearth-44">[39]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Style_guide" title="Style guide">House styles</a> now vary: <a href="/wiki/Oxford_spelling" title="Oxford spelling">Oxford spelling</a> recognizes the lowercase form as the most common, with the capitalized form an acceptable variant. Another convention capitalizes "Earth" when appearing as a name (e.g. "Earth's atmosphere") but writes it in lowercase when preceded by <i>the</i> (e.g. "the atmosphere of the earth"). It almost always appears in lowercase in colloquial expressions such as "what on earth are you doing?"<sup id="cite_ref-oxford_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oxford-62">[50]</a></sup></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Chronology">Chronology</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Earth" title="History of Earth">History of Earth</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Formation">Formation</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Protoplanetary-disk.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Protoplanetary-disk.jpg/220px-Protoplanetary-disk.jpg" width="220" height="119" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Protoplanetary-disk.jpg/330px-Protoplanetary-disk.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Protoplanetary-disk.jpg/440px-Protoplanetary-disk.jpg 2x" data-file-width="576" data-file-height="312"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Protoplanetary-disk.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Artist's impression of the early Solar System's planetary disk
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The oldest material found in the <a href="/wiki/Solar_System" title="Solar System">Solar System</a> is dated to <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7000456720000000000?</span>4.5672<span style="margin-left:0.3em;margin-right:0.15em;">±</span>0.0006&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Billion_years_ago" class="mw-redirect" title="Billion years ago">billion years ago</a></span> (Bya).<sup id="cite_ref-bowring_housch1995_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bowring_housch1995-63">[51]</a></sup> By <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7000454000000000000?</span>4.54<span style="margin-left:0.3em;margin-right:0.15em;">±</span>0.04&nbsp;Bya</span><sup id="cite_ref-age_earth1_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-age_earth1-64">[52]</a></sup> the primordial Earth had formed. The <a href="/wiki/Formation_and_evolution_of_the_Solar_System" title="Formation and evolution of the Solar System">formation and evolution of Solar System</a> bodies occurred along with the Sun. In theory, a <a href="/wiki/Solar_nebula" class="mw-redirect" title="Solar nebula">solar nebula</a> partitions a volume out of a <a href="/wiki/Molecular_cloud" title="Molecular cloud">molecular cloud</a> by gravitational collapse, which begins to spin and flatten into a <a href="/wiki/Circumstellar_disk" class="mw-redirect" title="Circumstellar disk">circumstellar disk</a>, and then the planets grow out of that disk along with the Sun. A nebula contains gas, ice grains, and <a href="/wiki/Cosmic_dust" title="Cosmic dust">dust</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Primordial_nuclide" title="Primordial nuclide">primordial nuclides</a>). According to <a href="/wiki/Nebular_theory" class="mw-redirect" title="Nebular theory">nebular theory</a>, <a href="/wiki/Planetesimal" title="Planetesimal">planetesimals</a> formed by <a href="/wiki/Accretion_(astrophysics)" title="Accretion (astrophysics)">accretion</a>, with the primordial Earth taking 10–<span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7001200000000000000?</span>20&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Million_years" class="mw-redirect" title="Million years">million years</a></span> (Mys) to form.<sup id="cite_ref-nature418_6901_949_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nature418_6901_949-65">[53]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>A subject of on-going research is the formation of the Moon, some 4.53 Bya.<sup id="cite_ref-science310_5754_1671_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-science310_5754_1671-66">[54]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Working_hypothesis" title="Working hypothesis">working hypothesis</a> is that it was formed by accretion from material loosed from Earth after a <a href="/wiki/Mars" title="Mars">Mars</a>-sized object, named <a href="/wiki/Theia_(planet)" title="Theia (planet)">Theia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Giant_impact_hypothesis" class="mw-redirect" title="Giant impact hypothesis">impacted</a> Earth.<sup id="cite_ref-reilly20091022_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reilly20091022-67">[55]</a></sup> In this scenario, the mass of Theia was approximately 10% of that of Earth,<sup id="cite_ref-canup_asphaug2001a_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-canup_asphaug2001a-68">[56]</a></sup> it impacted Earth with a glancing blow,<sup id="cite_ref-canup_asphaug2001b_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-canup_asphaug2001b-69">[57]</a></sup> and some of its mass merged with Earth. Between approximately 4.1 and <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7000380000000000000?</span>3.8&nbsp;Bya</span>, numerous <a href="/wiki/Impact_event" title="Impact event">asteroid impacts</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Late_Heavy_Bombardment" title="Late Heavy Bombardment">Late Heavy Bombardment</a> caused significant changes to the greater surface environment of the Moon, and by inference, to that of Earth.</p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Geological_history">Geological history</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Geological_history_of_Earth" title="Geological history of Earth">Geological history of Earth</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:USA_10654_Bryce_Canyon_Luca_Galuzzi_2007.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/USA_10654_Bryce_Canyon_Luca_Galuzzi_2007.jpg/220px-USA_10654_Bryce_Canyon_Luca_Galuzzi_2007.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/USA_10654_Bryce_Canyon_Luca_Galuzzi_2007.jpg/330px-USA_10654_Bryce_Canyon_Luca_Galuzzi_2007.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/USA_10654_Bryce_Canyon_Luca_Galuzzi_2007.jpg/440px-USA_10654_Bryce_Canyon_Luca_Galuzzi_2007.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1333"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:USA_10654_Bryce_Canyon_Luca_Galuzzi_2007.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> 
         <a href="/wiki/Hoodoo_(geology)" title="Hoodoo (geology)">Hoodoos</a> at the 
         <a href="/wiki/Bryce_Canyon_National_Park" title="Bryce Canyon National Park">Bryce Canyon National Park</a>, 
         <a href="/wiki/Utah" title="Utah">Utah</a>
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>Earth's atmosphere and oceans were formed by <a href="/wiki/Volcano" title="Volcano">volcanic activity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Outgassing" title="Outgassing">outgassing</a> that included water vapor. The <a href="/wiki/Origin_of_the_world%27s_oceans" class="mw-redirect" title="Origin of the world's oceans">origin of the world's oceans</a> was condensation augmented by water and ice delivered by asteroids, <a href="/wiki/Protoplanet" title="Protoplanet">protoplanets</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Comet" title="Comet">comets</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-watersource_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-watersource-70">[58]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Faint_young_Sun_paradox" title="Faint young Sun paradox">this model</a>, atmospheric "greenhouse gases" kept the oceans from freezing when the newly forming Sun had only 70% of its <a href="/wiki/Solar_luminosity" title="Solar luminosity">current luminosity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-asp2002_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-asp2002-71">[59]</a></sup> By <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7000350000000000000?</span>3.5&nbsp;Bya</span>, <a href="/wiki/Earth%27s_magnetic_field" title="Earth's magnetic field">Earth's magnetic field</a> was established, which helped prevent the atmosphere from being stripped away by the <a href="/wiki/Solar_wind" title="Solar wind">solar wind</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-physorg20100304_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-physorg20100304-72">[60]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>A crust formed when the molten outer layer of Earth cooled <a href="/wiki/Phase_transition" title="Phase transition">to form</a> a solid. The two models<sup id="cite_ref-williams_santosh2004_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-williams_santosh2004-73">[61]</a></sup> that explain land mass propose either a steady growth to the present-day forms<sup id="cite_ref-science164_1229_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-science164_1229-74">[62]</a></sup> or, more likely, a rapid growth<sup id="cite_ref-tp322_19_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tp322_19-75">[63]</a></sup> early in Earth history<sup id="cite_ref-rg6_175_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rg6_175-76">[64]</a></sup> followed by a long-term steady continental area.<sup id="cite_ref-science310_5756_1947_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-science310_5756_1947-77">[65]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-jaes23_799_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jaes23_799-78">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ajes38_613_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ajes38_613-79">[67]</a></sup> Continents formed by <a href="/wiki/Plate_tectonics" title="Plate tectonics">plate tectonics</a>, a process ultimately driven by the continuous loss of heat from Earth's interior. On <a href="/wiki/Geologic_time_scale" title="Geologic time scale">time scales</a> lasting hundreds of millions of years, the <a href="/wiki/Supercontinent" title="Supercontinent">supercontinents</a> have assembled and broken apart. Roughly <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7002750000000000000?</span>750&nbsp;million years ago</span> (Mya), one of the earliest known supercontinents, <a href="/wiki/Rodinia" title="Rodinia">Rodinia</a>, began to break apart. The continents later recombined to form <a href="/wiki/Pannotia" title="Pannotia">Pannotia</a>, 600–<span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7002540000000000000?</span>540&nbsp;Mya</span>, then finally <a href="/wiki/Pangaea" title="Pangaea">Pangaea</a>, which also broke apart <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7002180000000000000?</span>180&nbsp;Mya</span>.<sup id="cite_ref-as92_324_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-as92_324-80">[68]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The present pattern of <a href="/wiki/Ice_age" title="Ice age">ice ages</a> began about <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7001400000000000000?</span>40&nbsp;Mya</span> and then intensified during the <a href="/wiki/Pleistocene" title="Pleistocene">Pleistocene</a> about <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7000300000000000000?</span>3&nbsp;Mya</span>. High-<a href="/wiki/Latitude" title="Latitude">latitude</a> regions have since undergone repeated cycles of glaciation and thaw, repeating about every 40,000–<span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7012315576000000000?</span>100<span style="margin-left:.25em;">000</span>&nbsp;years</span>. The last continental glaciation ended 10,000&nbsp;years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-psc_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-psc-81">[69]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Origin_of_life_and_evolution">Origin of life and evolution</span></h3> 
      <div id="Container" class="toccolours searchaux" style="text-align: left; padding:0.5em 0 0 0; border-style:solid; float:right;clear:right; padding:0 0.5em; margin:0.3em 0 0.8em 1.4em; overflow: hidden;"> 
       <div id="Title" style="background-color:#77bb77; font-weight:bold; padding:0.2em; text-align:center; margin:0.6em 0 1.2em 0">
        <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_evolutionary_history_of_life" title="Timeline of the evolutionary history of life">Life timeline</a>
       </div> 
       <div id="Contains-Timeline-Scale-Notes"> 
        <div style="text-align:right; position:relative; top:-1em;">

        </div>

          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div class="bar" style="font-size:100%; background-color:blue; border-style: none; position:absolute; text-align:center; margin-top:0em; height:0.015859030837004em; margin-left:4.5em; width:5.5em;"> 
          <div class="nudge" style="font-size:100%; position:relative; top:-0.86em; left:0em;">
           <span style="position:relative; align:center; vertical-align:middle; bottom:-0.0079295154185022em;">&nbsp;</span>
          </div> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
        <div id="Annotations" style="float:left; position:relative; width:8.25em"> 
         <div class="annot-bar" style="width:auto; font-size:100%; position:absolute; text-align:center; margin-top:36em;"> 
          <div class="annot-arrow" style="position:relative; text-size:100%; top:-0.86em; left:0em; float:left;">
           <span style="color:black;">?</span>
          </div> 
          <div class="annot-nudge" style="text-size:100%; float:left; position:relative; text-align:left; top:-0.75em; left:0em; width:7em;"> 
           <div style="line-height:9pt">
            <span style="position:relative; width:auto; z-index:10; font-size:90%; color:black; vertical-align:middle; line-height:100%; bottom:0;"><a href="/wiki/History_of_Earth" title="History of Earth">Earliest Earth</a> (<a href="/wiki/Age_of_the_Earth" title="Age of the Earth">?4540</a>)</span>
           </div> 
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div class="annot-bar" style="width:auto; font-size:100%; position:absolute; text-align:center; margin-top:34.985022026432em;"> 
          <div class="annot-arrow" style="position:relative; text-size:100%; top:-0.86em; left:0em; float:left;">
           <span style="color:black;">?</span>
          </div>

        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div id="Legend" class="toccolours" style="margin-left:3.1em; border-style:none; float:left; clear:both;"></div> 
       <div id="Caption" class="toccolours" style="margin:0 0.5em; float:left; padding:0 auto; border-style:none; clear:both; text-align:center; width:20.5em">
        <a href="/wiki/Cartesian_coordinate_system#One_dimension" title="Cartesian coordinate system">Axis scale</a>: 
        <a href="/wiki/Geologic_time_scale" title="Geologic time scale">millions of years ago</a>.
        <br> 
        <small><span style="font:bold 10px Arial;display:inline;background-color:rgba(255,165,0,0.5);padding:0px 4px 0px 4px;"><span style="color:black;">Orange labels:</span> <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_glaciation" title="Timeline of glaciation"><span style="color:black;"><i><b>ice ages</b></i>.</span></a></span></small>
        <br> 
        <small>Also see: <i><a href="/wiki/Template:Human_timeline" title="Template:Human timeline">Human timeline</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Template:Nature_timeline" title="Template:Nature timeline">Nature timeline</a></i></small>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: 
       <a href="/wiki/Abiogenesis" title="Abiogenesis">Abiogenesis</a> and 
       <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_history_of_life" title="Evolutionary history of life">Evolutionary history of life</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:PhylogeneticTree,_Woese_1990.PNG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/PhylogeneticTree%2C_Woese_1990.PNG/220px-PhylogeneticTree%2C_Woese_1990.PNG" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/PhylogeneticTree%2C_Woese_1990.PNG/330px-PhylogeneticTree%2C_Woese_1990.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/PhylogeneticTree%2C_Woese_1990.PNG/440px-PhylogeneticTree%2C_Woese_1990.PNG 2x" data-file-width="1842" data-file-height="1257"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:PhylogeneticTree,_Woese_1990.PNG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> 
         <a href="/wiki/Phylogenetic_tree" title="Phylogenetic tree">Phylogenetic tree</a> of life on Earth based on 
         <a href="/wiki/RRNA" class="mw-redirect" title="RRNA">rRNA</a> analysis
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Chemical_reaction" title="Chemical reaction">Chemical reactions</a> led to the first self-replicating molecules about four billion years ago. A half billion years later, the <a href="/wiki/Last_universal_common_ancestor" title="Last universal common ancestor">last common ancestor of all life</a> arose.<sup id="cite_ref-sa282_6_90_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sa282_6_90-82">[70]</a></sup> The evolution of <a href="/wiki/Photosynthesis" title="Photosynthesis">photosynthesis</a> allowed the Sun's energy to be harvested directly by life forms. The resultant <a href="/wiki/Molecular_oxygen" class="mw-redirect" title="Molecular oxygen">molecular oxygen</a> (O<sub>2</sub>) accumulated in the atmosphere and due to interaction with ultraviolet solar radiation, formed a protective <a href="/wiki/Ozone_layer" title="Ozone layer">ozone layer</a> (O<sub>3</sub>) in the upper atmosphere.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT-20131003_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20131003-83">[71]</a></sup> The incorporation of smaller cells within larger ones resulted in the <a href="/wiki/Endosymbiotic_theory" class="mw-redirect" title="Endosymbiotic theory">development of complex cells</a> called <a href="/wiki/Eukaryote" title="Eukaryote">eukaryotes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-jas22_3_225_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jas22_3_225-84">[72]</a></sup> True multicellular organisms formed as cells within <a href="/wiki/Colony_(biology)" title="Colony (biology)">colonies</a> became increasingly specialized. Aided by the absorption of harmful <a href="/wiki/Ultraviolet_radiation" class="mw-redirect" title="Ultraviolet radiation">ultraviolet radiation</a> by the ozone layer, life colonized Earth's surface.<sup id="cite_ref-burton20021129_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-burton20021129-85">[73]</a></sup> Among the earliest <a href="/wiki/Fossil" title="Fossil">fossil</a> evidence for <a href="/wiki/Life" title="Life">life</a> is <a href="/wiki/Microbial_mat" title="Microbial mat">microbial mat</a> fossils found in 3.48&nbsp;billion-year-old <a href="/wiki/Sandstone" title="Sandstone">sandstone</a> in <a href="/wiki/Western_Australia" title="Western Australia">Western Australia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-AST-20131108_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AST-20131108-86">[74]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Biogenic_substance" title="Biogenic substance">biogenic</a> <a href="/wiki/Graphite" title="Graphite">graphite</a> found in 3.7&nbsp;billion-year-old <a href="/wiki/Metasediment" class="mw-redirect" title="Metasediment">metasedimentary rocks</a> in <a href="/wiki/Western_Greenland" class="mw-redirect" title="Western Greenland">Western Greenland</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-NG-20131208_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NG-20131208-87">[75]</a></sup> remains of <a href="/wiki/Biotic_material" title="Biotic material">biotic material</a> found in 4.1&nbsp;billion-year-old rocks in Western Australia.<sup id="cite_ref-AP-20151019_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AP-20151019-35">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PNAS-20151014-pdf_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PNAS-20151014-pdf-36">[31]</a></sup> 3.45 billion-year-old <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australian</a> rocks once contained <a href="/wiki/Microorganism" title="Microorganism">microorganisms</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Earliest_known_life_forms" title="Earliest known life forms">earliest direct evidence of life</a> on Earth.<sup id="cite_ref-WU-20171218_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WU-20171218-88">[76]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PNAS-2017_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PNAS-2017-89">[77]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>During the <a href="/wiki/Neoproterozoic" title="Neoproterozoic">Neoproterozoic</a>, <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7002750000000000000?</span>750 to 580&nbsp;Mya</span>, much of Earth might have been covered in ice. This hypothesis has been termed "<a href="/wiki/Snowball_Earth" title="Snowball Earth">Snowball Earth</a>", and it is of particular interest because it preceded the <a href="/wiki/Cambrian_explosion" title="Cambrian explosion">Cambrian explosion</a>, when multicellular life forms significantly increased in complexity.<sup id="cite_ref-kirschvink1992_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kirschvink1992-90">[78]</a></sup> Following the Cambrian explosion, <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7002535000000000000?</span>535&nbsp;Mya</span>, there have been five <a href="/wiki/Extinction_event" title="Extinction event">major mass extinctions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sci215_4539_1501_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sci215_4539_1501-91">[79]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Cretaceous%E2%80%93Tertiary_extinction_event" class="mw-redirect" title="Cretaceous–Tertiary extinction event">most recent such event</a> was <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7001660000000000000?</span>66&nbsp;Mya</span>, when <a href="/wiki/Chicxulub_impactor" title="Chicxulub impactor">an asteroid impact</a> triggered the extinction of the non-<a href="/wiki/Bird" title="Bird">avian</a> <a href="/wiki/Dinosaur" title="Dinosaur">dinosaurs</a> and other large reptiles, but spared some small animals such as <a href="/wiki/Mammal" title="Mammal">mammals</a>, which then resembled <a href="/wiki/Shrew" title="Shrew">shrews</a>. Over the past <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7001660000000000000?</span>66&nbsp;Mys</span>, mammalian life has diversified, and several million years ago an African ape-like animal such as <i><a href="/wiki/Orrorin_tugenensis" class="mw-redirect" title="Orrorin tugenensis">Orrorin tugenensis</a></i> gained the ability to stand upright.<sup id="cite_ref-gould1994_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gould1994-92">[80]</a></sup> This facilitated tool use and encouraged communication that provided the nutrition and stimulation needed for a larger brain, which allowed the <a href="/wiki/Human_evolution" title="Human evolution">evolution of humans</a>. The <a href="/wiki/History_of_agriculture" title="History of agriculture">development of agriculture</a>, and then <a href="/wiki/List_of_ancient_civilizations" class="mw-redirect" title="List of ancient civilizations">civilization</a>, led to humans having an <a href="/wiki/Human_impact_on_the_environment" title="Human impact on the environment">influence on Earth</a> and the nature and quantity of other life forms that continues today.<sup id="cite_ref-bgsa119_1_140_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bgsa119_1_140-93">[81]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Future">Future</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Future_of_Earth" title="Future of Earth">Future of Earth</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: 
       <a href="/wiki/Global_catastrophic_risk" title="Global catastrophic risk">Global catastrophic risk</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Earth's expected long-term future is closely tied to that of the Sun. Over the next <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7000110000000000000?</span>1.1&nbsp;Bys</span>, solar luminosity will increase by 10%, and over the next <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7000350000000000000?</span>3.5&nbsp;Bys</span> by 40%.<sup id="cite_ref-sun_future_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sun_future-94">[82]</a></sup> The Earth's increasing surface temperature will accelerate the <a href="/wiki/Inorganic" class="mw-redirect" title="Inorganic">inorganic</a> <a href="/wiki/Carbon_cycle" title="Carbon cycle">CO<sub>2</sub> cycle</a>, reducing its concentration to levels lethally low for plants (<span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">6995099999999999999?</span>10&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Parts_per_million" class="mw-redirect" title="Parts per million">ppm</a></span> for <a href="/wiki/C4_carbon_fixation" title="C4 carbon fixation">C4 photosynthesis</a>) in approximately 500–<span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7002900000000000000?</span>900&nbsp;Mys</span>.<sup id="cite_ref-britt2000_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britt2000-95">[83]</a></sup> The lack of vegetation will result in the loss of oxygen in the atmosphere, and animal life will become extinct.<sup id="cite_ref-ward_brownlee2002_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ward_brownlee2002-96">[84]</a></sup> After another billion years all surface water will have disappeared<sup id="cite_ref-carrington_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-carrington-97">[85]</a></sup> and the mean global temperature will reach <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7002343150000000000?</span>70&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Celsius" title="Celsius">°C</a></span><sup id="cite_ref-ward_brownlee2002_96-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ward_brownlee2002-96">[84]</a></sup> (<span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7002343150000000000?</span>158&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Fahrenheit" title="Fahrenheit">°F</a></span>). From that point, the Earth is expected to be habitable for another <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7016157788000000000?</span>500&nbsp;Ma</span>,<sup id="cite_ref-britt2000_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britt2000-95">[83]</a></sup> possibly up to <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7016725824800000000?</span>2.3&nbsp;Ga</span> if nitrogen is removed from the atmosphere.<sup id="cite_ref-pnas1_24_9576_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pnas1_24_9576-98">[86]</a></sup> Even if the Sun were eternal and stable, 27% of the water in the modern oceans will descend to the <a href="/wiki/Mantle_(geology)" title="Mantle (geology)">mantle</a> in one billion years, due to reduced steam venting from mid-ocean ridges.<sup id="cite_ref-hess5_4_569_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hess5_4_569-99">[87]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The Sun will <a href="/wiki/Stellar_evolution" title="Stellar evolution">evolve</a> to become a <a href="/wiki/Red_giant" title="Red giant">red giant</a> in about <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7000500000000000000?</span>5&nbsp;Bys</span>. Models predict that the Sun will expand to roughly 1&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Astronomical_unit" title="Astronomical unit">AU</a> (150&nbsp;million&nbsp;km; 93&nbsp;million&nbsp;mi), which is about 250 times its present radius.<sup id="cite_ref-sun_future_94-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sun_future-94">[82]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-sun_future_schroder_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sun_future_schroder-100">[88]</a></sup> Earth's fate is less clear. As a red giant, the Sun will lose roughly 30% of its mass, so, without tidal effects, Earth will move to an orbit 1.7&nbsp;AU (250&nbsp;million&nbsp;km; 160&nbsp;million&nbsp;mi) from the Sun when the star reaches its maximum radius. Most, if not all, remaining life will be destroyed by the Sun's increased luminosity (peaking at about 5,000 times its present level).<sup id="cite_ref-sun_future_94-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sun_future-94">[82]</a></sup> A 2008 simulation indicates that Earth's orbit will eventually decay due to <a href="/wiki/Tidal_acceleration" title="Tidal acceleration">tidal effects</a> and drag, causing it to enter the Sun's atmosphere and be vaporized.<sup id="cite_ref-sun_future_schroder_100-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sun_future_schroder-100">[88]</a></sup></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Physical_characteristics">Physical characteristics</span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Shape">Shape</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg/220px-Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg" width="220" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg/330px-Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg/440px-Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1362"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Earth2014shape_SouthAmerica_small.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Shape of planet Earth. Shown are distances between surface relief and the geocentre. The South American Andes summits are visible as elevated areas. Data from the Earth2014
         <sup id="cite_ref-Earth2014_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Earth2014-101">[89]</a></sup> global relief model.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Figure_of_the_Earth" title="Figure of the Earth">Figure of the Earth</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The shape of Earth is approximately <a href="/wiki/Oblate_spheroid" class="mw-redirect" title="Oblate spheroid">oblate spheroidal</a>. Due to <a href="/wiki/Rotation" title="Rotation">rotation</a>, the Earth is flattened along the geographic axis and <a href="/wiki/Equatorial_bulge" title="Equatorial bulge">bulging</a> around the <a href="/wiki/Equator" title="Equator">equator</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-milbert_smith96_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milbert_smith96-102">[90]</a></sup> The diameter of the Earth at the equator is 43 kilometres (27&nbsp;mi) larger than the <a href="/wiki/Geographical_pole" title="Geographical pole">pole</a>-to-pole diameter.<sup id="cite_ref-ngdc2006_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ngdc2006-103">[91]</a></sup> Thus the point on the surface farthest from Earth's <a href="/wiki/Center_of_mass" title="Center of mass">center of mass</a> is the summit of the equatorial <a href="/wiki/Chimborazo_(volcano)" class="mw-redirect" title="Chimborazo (volcano)">Chimborazo</a> volcano in <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ps20_5_16_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ps20_5_16-104">[92]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-lancet365_9462_831_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lancet365_9462_831-105">[93]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-tall_tales_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tall_tales-106">[94]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_'Highest'_Spot_on_Earth_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_'Highest'_Spot_on_Earth-107">[95]</a></sup> The average diameter of the reference spheroid is 12,742 kilometres (7,918&nbsp;mi). Local <a href="/wiki/Topography" title="Topography">topography</a> deviates from this idealized spheroid, although on a global scale these deviations are small compared to Earth's radius: The maximum deviation of only 0.17% is at the <a href="/wiki/Mariana_Trench" title="Mariana Trench">Mariana Trench</a> (10,911 metres (35,797&nbsp;ft) below local sea level), whereas <a href="/wiki/Mount_Everest" title="Mount Everest">Mount Everest</a> (8,848 metres (29,029&nbsp;ft) above local sea level) represents a deviation of 0.14%.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[n 13]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>In <a href="/wiki/Geodesy" title="Geodesy">geodesy</a>, the exact shape that Earth's oceans would adopt in the absence of land and perturbations such as tides and winds is called the <a href="/wiki/Geoid" title="Geoid">geoid</a>. More precisely, the geoid is the surface of gravitational equipotential at <a href="/wiki/Mean_sea_level" class="mw-redirect" title="Mean sea level">mean sea level</a>.</p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Chemical_composition">Chemical composition</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: 
       <a href="/wiki/Abundance_of_elements_on_Earth" class="mw-redirect" title="Abundance of elements on Earth">Abundance of elements on Earth</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="float: right; clear: right; margin-left: 2em;"> 
       <caption>
        Chemical composition of the crust
        <sup id="cite_ref-brown_mussett1981_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brown_mussett1981-110">[97]</a></sup>
       </caption>

        <tr>

         <td style="text-align: right;">1.2%</td> 
         <td style="text-align: right;">1.4%</td>

         <td style="text-align: right;">0.7%</td> 
         <td style="text-align: right;">1.4%</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Phosphorus_pentoxide" title="Phosphorus pentoxide">phosphorus pentoxide</a></td>

         <td style="text-align: right;">0.3%</td>

        <tr> 
         <th colspan="2">Total</th> 
         <th style="text-align: right;">99.6%</th> 
         <th style="text-align: right;">99.9%</th> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Earth_mass" title="Earth mass">Earth's mass</a> is approximately <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7024597000000000000?</span>5.97<span style="margin-left:0.25em;margin-right:0.15em;">×</span>10<sup>24</sup>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Kilogram" title="Kilogram">kg</a></span> (5,970 <a href="/wiki/Yottagram" class="mw-redirect" title="Yottagram">Yg</a>). It is composed mostly of <a href="/wiki/Iron" title="Iron">iron</a> (32.1%), <a href="/wiki/Oxygen" title="Oxygen">oxygen</a> (30.1%), <a href="/wiki/Silicon" title="Silicon">silicon</a> (15.1%), <a href="/wiki/Magnesium" title="Magnesium">magnesium</a> (13.9%), <a href="/wiki/Sulfur" title="Sulfur">sulfur</a> (2.9%), <a href="/wiki/Nickel" title="Nickel">nickel</a> (1.8%), <a href="/wiki/Calcium" title="Calcium">calcium</a> (1.5%), and <a href="/wiki/Aluminium" title="Aluminium">aluminium</a> (1.4%), with the remaining 1.2% consisting of trace amounts of other elements. Due to <a href="/wiki/Mass_segregation" class="mw-redirect" title="Mass segregation">mass segregation</a>, the core region is estimated to be primarily composed of iron (88.8%), with smaller amounts of nickel (5.8%), sulfur (4.5%), and less than 1% trace elements.<sup id="cite_ref-pnas71_12_6973_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pnas71_12_6973-111">[98]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The most common rock constituents of the crust are nearly all oxides: chlorine, sulfur, and fluorine are the important exceptions to this and their total amount in any rock is usually much less than 1%. Over 99% of the crust is composed of 11 oxides, principally silica, alumina, iron oxides, lime, magnesia, potash, and soda.<sup id="cite_ref-brown_mussett1981_110-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brown_mussett1981-110">[97]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-pnas71_12_6973_111-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pnas71_12_6973-111">[98]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[99]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Internal_structure">Internal structure</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Structure_of_the_Earth" title="Structure of the Earth">Structure of the Earth</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Earth's interior, like that of the other terrestrial planets, is divided into layers by their <a href="/wiki/Chemical" class="mw-redirect" title="Chemical">chemical</a> or physical (<a href="/wiki/Rheology" title="Rheology">rheological</a>) properties. The outer layer is a chemically distinct <a href="/wiki/Silicate_minerals" title="Silicate minerals">silicate</a> solid crust, which is underlain by a highly <a href="/wiki/Viscous" class="mw-redirect" title="Viscous">viscous</a> solid mantle. The crust is separated from the mantle by the <a href="/wiki/Mohorovi%C4%8Di%C4%87_discontinuity" title="Mohorovi?i? discontinuity">Mohorovi?i? discontinuity</a>. The thickness of the crust varies from about <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7003600000000000000?</span>6&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Kilometre" title="Kilometre">km</a></span> (kilometers) under the oceans to 30–50&nbsp;km for the continents. The crust and the cold, rigid, top of the <a href="/wiki/Upper_mantle" class="mw-redirect" title="Upper mantle">upper mantle</a> are collectively known as the lithosphere, and it is of the lithosphere that the tectonic plates are composed. Beneath the lithosphere is the <a href="/wiki/Asthenosphere" title="Asthenosphere">asthenosphere</a>, a relatively low-viscosity layer on which the lithosphere rides. Important changes in crystal structure within the mantle occur at 410 and <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7005660000000000000?</span>660&nbsp;km</span> below the surface, spanning a <a href="/wiki/Transition_zone_(Earth)" title="Transition zone (Earth)">transition zone</a> that separates the upper and lower mantle. Beneath the mantle, an extremely low viscosity liquid <a href="/wiki/Outer_core" title="Outer core">outer core</a> lies above a solid <a href="/wiki/Inner_core" title="Inner core">inner core</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-tanimoto_ahrens1995_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tanimoto_ahrens1995-113">[100]</a></sup> The Earth's inner core might rotate at a slightly higher <a href="/wiki/Angular_velocity" title="Angular velocity">angular velocity</a> than the remainder of the planet, advancing by 0.1–0.5° per year.<sup id="cite_ref-science309_5739_1313_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-science309_5739_1313-114">[101]</a></sup> The radius of the inner core is about one fifth of that of Earth.</p> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;"> 
       <caption>
        Geologic layers of Earth
        <sup id="cite_ref-pnas76_9_4192_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pnas76_9_4192-115">[102]</a></sup>
       </caption> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th rowspan="8" style="font-size:smaller; text-align:center;"> 
          <div class="center"> 
           <div class="floatnone">
            <a href="/wiki/File:Earth-cutaway-schematic-english.svg" class="image"><img alt="Earth-cutaway-schematic-english.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Earth-cutaway-schematic-english.svg/220px-Earth-cutaway-schematic-english.svg.png" width="220" height="155" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Earth-cutaway-schematic-english.svg/330px-Earth-cutaway-schematic-english.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Earth-cutaway-schematic-english.svg/440px-Earth-cutaway-schematic-english.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="900"></a>

      </table> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Heat">Heat</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Earth%27s_internal_heat_budget" title="Earth's internal heat budget">Earth's internal heat budget</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Earth's <a href="/wiki/Internal_heat" class="mw-redirect" title="Internal heat">internal heat</a> comes from a combination of residual heat from <a href="/wiki/Planetary_accretion" class="mw-redirect" title="Planetary accretion">planetary accretion</a> (about 20%) and heat produced through <a href="/wiki/Radioactive_decay" title="Radioactive decay">radioactive decay</a> (80%).<sup id="cite_ref-turcotte_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-turcotte-119">[104]</a></sup> The major heat-producing <a href="/wiki/Isotope" title="Isotope">isotopes</a> within Earth are <a href="/wiki/Potassium-40" title="Potassium-40">potassium-40</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uranium-238" title="Uranium-238">uranium-238</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Thorium-232" class="mw-redirect" title="Thorium-232">thorium-232</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sanders20031210_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sanders20031210-120">[105]</a></sup> At the center, the temperature may be up to 6,000&nbsp;°C (10,830&nbsp;°F),<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[106]</a></sup> and the pressure could reach 360&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/GPa" class="mw-redirect" title="GPa">GPa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ptrsl360_1795_1227_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ptrsl360_1795_1227-122">[107]</a></sup> Because much of the heat is provided by radioactive decay, scientists postulate that early in Earth's history, before isotopes with short half-lives were depleted, Earth's heat production was much higher. At approximately <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7016946728000000000?</span>3&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Year#SI_prefix_multipliers" title="Year">Ga</a></span>, twice the present-day heat would have been produced, increasing the rates of <a href="/wiki/Mantle_convection" title="Mantle convection">mantle convection</a> and plate tectonics, and allowing the production of uncommon igneous rocks such as <a href="/wiki/Komatiites" class="mw-redirect" title="Komatiites">komatiites</a> that are rarely formed today.<sup id="cite_ref-turcotte_119-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-turcotte-119">[104]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-epsl121_1_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-epsl121_1-123">[108]</a></sup></p> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;"> 
       <caption>
        Present-day major heat-producing isotopes
        <sup id="cite_ref-T&amp;S_137_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-T&amp;S_137-124">[109]</a></sup>
       </caption> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th>Isotope</th> 
         <th>Heat release<br> <span style="font-size: smaller;"><span class="sfrac nowrap" style="display:inline-block; vertical-align:-0.5em; font-size:85%; text-align:center;"><span style="display:block; line-height:1em; margin:0 0.1em;">W</span><span class="visualhide">/</span><span style="display:block; line-height:1em; margin:0 0.1em; border-top:1px solid;">kg isotope</span></span></span></th> 
         <th>Half-life<br> <span style="font-size: smaller;">years</span></th> 
         <th>Mean mantle concentration<br> <span style="font-size: smaller;"><span class="sfrac nowrap" style="display:inline-block; vertical-align:-0.5em; font-size:85%; text-align:center;"><span style="display:block; line-height:1em; margin:0 0.1em;">kg isotope</span><span class="visualhide">/</span><span style="display:block; line-height:1em; margin:0 0.1em; border-top:1px solid;">kg mantle</span></span></span></th> 
         <th>Heat release<br> <span style="font-size: smaller;"><span class="sfrac nowrap" style="display:inline-block; vertical-align:-0.5em; font-size:85%; text-align:center;"><span style="display:block; line-height:1em; margin:0 0.1em;">W</span><span class="visualhide">/</span><span style="display:block; line-height:1em; margin:0 0.1em; border-top:1px solid;">kg mantle</span></span></span></th> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><sup>238</sup>U</td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">94.6 × 10<sup>?6</sup></span></td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">4.47 × 10<sup>9</sup></span></td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">30.8 × 10<sup>?9</sup></span></td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">2.91 × 10<sup>?12</sup></span></td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><sup>235</sup>U</td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">569 × 10<sup>?6</sup></span></td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">0.704 × 10<sup>9</sup></span></td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">0.22 × 10<sup>?9</sup></span></td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">0.125 × 10<sup>?12</sup></span></td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><sup>232</sup>Th</td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">26.4 × 10<sup>?6</sup></span></td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">14.0 × 10<sup>9</sup></span></td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">124 × 10<sup>?9</sup></span></td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">3.27 × 10<sup>?12</sup></span></td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><sup>40</sup>K</td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">29.2 × 10<sup>?6</sup></span></td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">1.25 × 10<sup>9</sup></span></td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">36.9 × 10<sup>?9</sup></span></td> 
         <td><span class="nowrap">1.08 × 10<sup>?12</sup></span></td> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>The mean heat loss from Earth is <span class="nowrap">87 mW m<sup>?2</sup></span>, for a global heat loss of <span class="nowrap">4.42 × 10<sup>13</sup> W</span>.<sup id="cite_ref-jg31_3_267_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jg31_3_267-125">[110]</a></sup> A portion of the core's thermal energy is transported toward the crust by <a href="/wiki/Mantle_plume" title="Mantle plume">mantle plumes</a>, a form of convection consisting of upwellings of higher-temperature rock. These plumes can produce <a href="/wiki/Hotspot_(geology)" title="Hotspot (geology)">hotspots</a> and <a href="/wiki/Flood_basalt" title="Flood basalt">flood basalts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-science246_4926_103_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-science246_4926_103-126">[111]</a></sup> More of the heat in Earth is lost through plate tectonics, by mantle upwelling associated with <a href="/wiki/Mid-ocean_ridge" title="Mid-ocean ridge">mid-ocean ridges</a>. The final major mode of heat loss is through conduction through the lithosphere, the majority of which occurs under the oceans because the crust there is much thinner than that of the continents.<sup id="cite_ref-heat_loss_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-heat_loss-127">[112]</a></sup></p> 
      <div style="clear:right;"></div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tectonic_plates">Tectonic plates</span></h3> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin-left:1em;">

        <a href="/wiki/List_of_tectonic_plates" title="List of tectonic plates">Earth's major plates</a>

       </caption> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td colspan="2" style="font-size: smaller; text-align: center;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tectonic_plates_(empty).svg" class="image"><img alt="Shows the extent and boundaries of tectonic plates, with superimposed outlines of the continents they support" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Tectonic_plates_%28empty%29.svg/220px-Tectonic_plates_%28empty%29.svg.png" width="220" height="149" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Tectonic_plates_%28empty%29.svg/330px-Tectonic_plates_%28empty%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Tectonic_plates_%28empty%29.svg/440px-Tectonic_plates_%28empty%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="681" data-file-height="461"></a></td>

          </div> </td>

        <tr> 
         <td> 
          <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
           <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #7fa172; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;
           <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Plate" title="Eurasian Plate">Eurasian Plate</a>
          </div> </td> 
         <td style="text-align: center;">67.8</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td> 
          <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
           <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #8a9dbe; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;
           <a href="/wiki/Antarctic_Plate" title="Antarctic Plate">Antarctic Plate</a>
          </div> </td> 
         <td style="text-align: center;">60.9</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td> 
          <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
           <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #fcb482; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;
           <a href="/wiki/Indo-Australian_Plate" title="Indo-Australian Plate">Indo-Australian Plate</a>
          </div> </td> 
         <td style="text-align: center;">47.2</td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td> 
          <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
           <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #ad82b0; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;
           <a href="/wiki/South_American_Plate" title="South American Plate">South American Plate</a>
          </div> </td> 
         <td style="text-align: center;">43.6</td> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Plate_tectonics" title="Plate tectonics">Plate tectonics</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The mechanically rigid outer layer of Earth, the lithosphere, is divided into pieces called tectonic plates. These plates are rigid segments that move in relation to one another at one of three types of plate boundaries: <a href="/wiki/Convergent_boundary" title="Convergent boundary">convergent boundaries</a>, at which two plates come together, <a href="/wiki/Divergent_boundary" title="Divergent boundary">divergent boundaries</a>, at which two plates are pulled apart, and <a href="/wiki/Transform_boundary" class="mw-redirect" title="Transform boundary">transform boundaries</a>, in which two plates slide past one another laterally. <a href="/wiki/Earthquake" title="Earthquake">Earthquakes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Volcanism" title="Volcanism">volcanic activity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orogeny" title="Orogeny">mountain-building</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_trench" title="Oceanic trench">oceanic trench</a> formation can occur along these plate boundaries.<sup id="cite_ref-kious_tilling1999_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kious_tilling1999-130">[114]</a></sup> The tectonic plates ride on top of the asthenosphere, the solid but less-viscous part of the upper mantle that can flow and move along with the plates.<sup id="cite_ref-seligman2008_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-seligman2008-131">[115]</a></sup></p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mount-Everest.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Mount-Everest.jpg/220px-Mount-Everest.jpg" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Mount-Everest.jpg/330px-Mount-Everest.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Mount-Everest.jpg/440px-Mount-Everest.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2679" data-file-height="1781"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mount-Everest.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> 
         <a href="/wiki/Orogeny" title="Orogeny">Mountain building</a> occurs when tectonic plates move toward each other, forcing rock up. The largest 
         <a href="/wiki/Mountain" title="Mountain">mountain</a> on Earth is 
         <a href="/wiki/Mount_Everest" title="Mount Everest">Mount Everest</a>.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>As the tectonic plates migrate, oceanic crust is <a href="/wiki/Subduction" title="Subduction">subducted</a> under the leading edges of the plates at convergent boundaries. At the same time, the upwelling of mantle material at divergent boundaries creates mid-ocean ridges. The combination of these processes recycles the <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_crust" title="Oceanic crust">oceanic crust</a> back into the mantle. Due to this recycling, most of the ocean floor is less than <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7015315576000000000?</span>100&nbsp;Ma</span> old in age. The oldest oceanic crust is located in the Western Pacific and has an estimated age of <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7015631152000000000?</span>200&nbsp;Ma</span>.<sup id="cite_ref-duennebier1999_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-duennebier1999-132">[116]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-noaa20070307_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-noaa20070307-133">[117]</a></sup> By comparison, the oldest dated <a href="/wiki/Continental_crust" title="Continental crust">continental crust</a> is <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7017127177128000000?</span>4030&nbsp;Ma</span>.<sup id="cite_ref-cmp134_3_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cmp134_3-134">[118]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The seven major plates are the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Plate" title="Pacific Plate">Pacific</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_American_Plate" title="North American Plate">North American</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Plate" title="Eurasian Plate">Eurasian</a>, <a href="/wiki/African_Plate" title="African Plate">African</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antarctic_Plate" title="Antarctic Plate">Antarctic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indo-Australian_Plate" title="Indo-Australian Plate">Indo-Australian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/South_American_Plate" title="South American Plate">South American</a>. Other notable plates include the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Plate" title="Arabian Plate">Arabian Plate</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Plate" title="Caribbean Plate">Caribbean Plate</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Nazca_Plate" title="Nazca Plate">Nazca Plate</a> off the west coast of South America and the <a href="/wiki/Scotia_Plate" title="Scotia Plate">Scotia Plate</a> in the southern Atlantic Ocean. The Australian Plate fused with the Indian Plate between 50 and <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7001550000000000000?</span>55&nbsp;Mya</span>. The fastest-moving plates are the oceanic plates, with the <a href="/wiki/Cocos_Plate" title="Cocos Plate">Cocos Plate</a> advancing at a rate of 75&nbsp;mm/year<sup id="cite_ref-podp2000_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-podp2000-135">[119]</a></sup> and the Pacific Plate moving 52–69&nbsp;mm/year. At the other extreme, the slowest-moving plate is the Eurasian Plate, progressing at a typical rate of 21&nbsp;mm/year.<sup id="cite_ref-gps_time_series_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gps_time_series-136">[120]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Surface">Surface</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: 
       <a href="/wiki/Lithosphere" title="Lithosphere">Lithosphere</a>, 
       <a href="/wiki/Landform" title="Landform">Landform</a>, and 
       <a href="/wiki/Extreme_points_of_Earth" title="Extreme points of Earth">Extreme points of Earth</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:AYool_topography_15min.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/AYool_topography_15min.png/220px-AYool_topography_15min.png" width="220" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/AYool_topography_15min.png/330px-AYool_topography_15min.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/AYool_topography_15min.png/440px-AYool_topography_15min.png 2x" data-file-width="1617" data-file-height="1133"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:AYool_topography_15min.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Present-day Earth 
         <a href="/wiki/Terrain" title="Terrain">altimetry</a> and 
         <a href="/wiki/Bathymetry" title="Bathymetry">bathymetry</a>. Data from the 
         <a href="/wiki/National_Geophysical_Data_Center" title="National Geophysical Data Center">National Geophysical Data Center</a>.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The total <a href="/wiki/Spheroid#Area" title="Spheroid">surface area</a> of the Earth is about 510&nbsp;million&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (197&nbsp;million&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-Pidwirny_2006_8_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pidwirny_2006_8-16">[13]</a></sup> Of this, 70.8%,<sup id="cite_ref-Pidwirny_2006_8_16-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pidwirny_2006_8-16">[13]</a></sup> or 361.13&nbsp;million&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (139.43&nbsp;million&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), is below sea level and covered by ocean water.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[121]</a></sup> Below the ocean's surface are much of the <a href="/wiki/Continental_shelf" title="Continental shelf">continental shelf</a>, mountains, volcanoes,<sup id="cite_ref-ngdc2006_103-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ngdc2006-103">[91]</a></sup> oceanic trenches, <a href="/wiki/Submarine_canyon" title="Submarine canyon">submarine canyons</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_plateau" title="Oceanic plateau">oceanic plateaus</a>, abyssal plains, and a globe-spanning mid-ocean ridge system. The remaining 29.2%, or 148.94&nbsp;million&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (57.51&nbsp;million&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), not covered by water has <a href="/wiki/Terrain" title="Terrain">terrain</a> that varies greatly from place to place and consists of mountains, deserts, plains, plateaus, and other <a href="/wiki/Landform" title="Landform">landforms</a>. <a href="/wiki/Erosion_and_tectonics" title="Erosion and tectonics">Tectonics and erosion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Types_of_volcanic_eruptions" title="Types of volcanic eruptions">volcanic eruptions</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flooding" class="mw-redirect" title="Flooding">flooding</a>, <a href="/wiki/Weathering" title="Weathering">weathering</a>, <a href="/wiki/Glaciation" class="mw-redirect" title="Glaciation">glaciation</a>, the growth of <a href="/wiki/Coral_reef" title="Coral reef">coral reefs</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Impact_event" title="Impact event">meteorite impacts</a> are among the processes that constantly reshape the Earth's surface over <a href="/wiki/Geological_time" class="mw-redirect" title="Geological time">geological time</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-kring_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kring-138">[122]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[123]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The continental crust consists of lower density material such as the igneous rocks <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">granite</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andesite" title="Andesite">andesite</a>. Less common is <a href="/wiki/Basalt" title="Basalt">basalt</a>, a denser volcanic rock that is the primary constituent of the ocean floors.<sup id="cite_ref-layers_earth_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-layers_earth-140">[124]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sedimentary_rock" title="Sedimentary rock">Sedimentary rock</a> is formed from the accumulation of sediment that becomes buried and <a href="/wiki/Diagenesis" title="Diagenesis">compacted together</a>. Nearly 75% of the continental surfaces are covered by sedimentary rocks, although they form about 5% of the crust.<sup id="cite_ref-jessey_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jessey-141">[125]</a></sup> The third form of rock material found on Earth is <a href="/wiki/Metamorphic_rock" title="Metamorphic rock">metamorphic rock</a>, which is created from the transformation of pre-existing rock types through high pressures, high temperatures, or both. The most abundant <a href="/wiki/Silicate_mineral" class="mw-redirect" title="Silicate mineral">silicate minerals</a> on Earth's surface include <a href="/wiki/Quartz" title="Quartz">quartz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Feldspar" title="Feldspar">feldspars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amphibole" title="Amphibole">amphibole</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mica" title="Mica">mica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pyroxene" title="Pyroxene">pyroxene</a> and <a href="/wiki/Olivine" title="Olivine">olivine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-de_pater_lissauer2010_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-de_pater_lissauer2010-142">[126]</a></sup> Common <a href="/wiki/Carbonate_mineral" class="mw-redirect" title="Carbonate mineral">carbonate minerals</a> include <a href="/wiki/Calcite" title="Calcite">calcite</a> (found in <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">limestone</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Dolomite" title="Dolomite">dolomite</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-wekn_bulakh2004_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wekn_bulakh2004-143">[127]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The elevation of the land surface varies from the low point of ?418&nbsp;m (?1,371&nbsp;ft) at the <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea" title="Dead Sea">Dead Sea</a>, to a maximum altitude of 8,848&nbsp;m (29,029&nbsp;ft) at the top of Mount Everest. The mean height of land above sea level is about 797&nbsp;m (2,615&nbsp;ft).<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[128]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Pedosphere" title="Pedosphere">pedosphere</a> is the outermost layer of Earth's continental surface and is composed of <a href="/wiki/Soil" title="Soil">soil</a> and subject to <a href="/wiki/Pedogenesis" title="Pedogenesis">soil formation processes</a>. The total arable land is 10.9% of the land surface, with 1.3% being permanent cropland.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[130]</a></sup> Close to 40% of Earth's land surface is used for agriculture, or an estimated 16.7&nbsp;million&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (6.4&nbsp;million&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) of cropland and 33.5&nbsp;million&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (12.9&nbsp;million&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) of pastureland.<sup id="cite_ref-Hooke2012_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hooke2012-147">[131]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hydrosphere">Hydrosphere</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Hydrosphere" title="Hydrosphere">Hydrosphere</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Earth_elevation_histogram_2.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Earth_elevation_histogram_2.svg/220px-Earth_elevation_histogram_2.svg.png" width="220" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Earth_elevation_histogram_2.svg/330px-Earth_elevation_histogram_2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Earth_elevation_histogram_2.svg/440px-Earth_elevation_histogram_2.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="582" data-file-height="441"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Earth_elevation_histogram_2.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Elevation histogram of Earth's surface
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The abundance of water on Earth's surface is a unique feature that distinguishes the "Blue Planet" from other planets in the Solar System. Earth's hydrosphere consists chiefly of the oceans, but technically includes all water surfaces in the world, including inland seas, lakes, rivers, and underground waters down to a depth of 2,000&nbsp;m (6,600&nbsp;ft). The deepest underwater location is <a href="/wiki/Challenger_Deep" title="Challenger Deep">Challenger Deep</a> of the Mariana Trench in the Pacific Ocean with a depth of 10,911.4&nbsp;m (35,799&nbsp;ft).<sup id="cite_ref-trench_depth_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-trench_depth-148">[n 17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-kaiko7000_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kaiko7000-149">[132]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The mass of the oceans is approximately 1.35<span style="margin:0 .15em 0 .25em">×</span>10<sup><span style="white-space:nowrap">18</span></sup>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Metric_ton" class="mw-redirect" title="Metric ton">metric tons</a> or about 1/4400 of Earth's total mass. The oceans cover an area of <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7014361800000000000?</span>3.618<span style="margin-left:0.25em;margin-right:0.15em;">×</span>10<sup>8</sup>&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup></span> with a mean depth of <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7003368200000000000?</span>3682&nbsp;m</span>, resulting in an estimated volume of <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7018133200000000000?</span>1.332<span style="margin-left:0.25em;margin-right:0.15em;">×</span>10<sup>9</sup>&nbsp;km<sup>3</sup></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-ocean23_2_112_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ocean23_2_112-150">[133]</a></sup> If all of Earth's crustal surface were at the same elevation as a smooth sphere, the depth of the resulting world ocean would be 2.7 to 2.8&nbsp;km.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[134]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[135]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>About 97.5% of the water is <a href="/wiki/Saline_water" title="Saline water">saline</a>; the remaining 2.5% is <a href="/wiki/Fresh_water" title="Fresh water">fresh water</a>. Most fresh water, about 68.7%, is present as ice in <a href="/wiki/Ice_cap" title="Ice cap">ice caps</a> and <a href="/wiki/Glacier" title="Glacier">glaciers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[136]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The average <a href="/wiki/Salinity" title="Salinity">salinity</a> of Earth's oceans is about 35&nbsp;grams of salt per kilogram of sea water (3.5% salt).<sup id="cite_ref-kennish2001_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kennish2001-154">[137]</a></sup> Most of this salt was released from volcanic activity or extracted from cool igneous rocks.<sup id="cite_ref-mullen2002_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mullen2002-155">[138]</a></sup> The oceans are also a reservoir of dissolved atmospheric gases, which are essential for the survival of many aquatic life forms.<sup id="cite_ref-natsci_oxy4_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natsci_oxy4-156">[139]</a></sup> Sea water has an important influence on the world's climate, with the oceans acting as a large <a href="/wiki/Heat_reservoir" class="mw-redirect" title="Heat reservoir">heat reservoir</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-michon2006_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-michon2006-157">[140]</a></sup> Shifts in the oceanic temperature distribution can cause significant weather shifts, such as the <a href="/wiki/El_Ni%C3%B1o-Southern_Oscillation" class="mw-redirect" title="El Niño-Southern Oscillation">El Niño-Southern Oscillation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sample2005_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sample2005-158">[141]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Atmosphere">Atmosphere</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Atmosphere_of_Earth" title="Atmosphere of Earth">Atmosphere of Earth</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:MODIS_Map.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/MODIS_Map.jpg/220px-MODIS_Map.jpg" width="220" height="110" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/MODIS_Map.jpg/330px-MODIS_Map.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/MODIS_Map.jpg/440px-MODIS_Map.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5400" data-file-height="2700"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:MODIS_Map.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Satellite image of Earth 
         <a href="/wiki/Cloud_cover" title="Cloud cover">cloud cover</a> using 
         <a href="/wiki/NASA" title="NASA">NASA</a>'s 
         <a href="/wiki/Moderate-Resolution_Imaging_Spectroradiometer" class="mw-redirect" title="Moderate-Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer">Moderate-Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer</a>
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Atmospheric_pressure" title="Atmospheric pressure">atmospheric pressure</a> on Earth's surface averages 101.325&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/KPa" class="mw-redirect" title="KPa">kPa</a>, with a <a href="/wiki/Scale_height" title="Scale height">scale height</a> of about 8.5&nbsp;km.<sup id="cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-earth_fact_sheet-5">[3]</a></sup> It has a composition of 78% <a href="/wiki/Nitrogen" title="Nitrogen">nitrogen</a> and 21% oxygen, with trace amounts of <a href="/wiki/Water_vapor" title="Water vapor">water vapor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a>, and other gaseous molecules. The height of the <a href="/wiki/Troposphere" title="Troposphere">troposphere</a> varies with latitude, ranging between 8&nbsp;km at the poles to 17&nbsp;km at the equator, with some variation resulting from weather and seasonal factors.<sup id="cite_ref-geerts_linacre97_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-geerts_linacre97-159">[142]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Earth's <a href="/wiki/Biosphere" title="Biosphere">biosphere</a> has significantly altered its <a href="/wiki/Atmosphere_of_Earth" title="Atmosphere of Earth">atmosphere</a>. <a href="/wiki/Oxygen_evolution#Oxygen_evolution_in_nature" title="Oxygen evolution">Oxygenic photosynthesis</a> evolved <span class="nowrap"><span style="display:none" class="sortkey">7000270000000000000?</span>2.7&nbsp;Gya</span>, <a href="/wiki/Oxygen_catastrophe" class="mw-redirect" title="Oxygen catastrophe">forming</a> the primarily nitrogen–oxygen atmosphere of today.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT-20131003_83-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20131003-83">[71]</a></sup> This change enabled the proliferation of <a href="/wiki/Aerobic_organisms" class="mw-redirect" title="Aerobic organisms">aerobic organisms</a> and, indirectly, the formation of the <a href="/wiki/Ozone_layer" title="Ozone layer">ozone layer</a> due to the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Ozone%E2%80%93oxygen_cycle" title="Ozone–oxygen cycle">conversion of atmospheric O<sub>2</sub> into O<sub>3</sub></a>. The ozone layer blocks <a href="/wiki/Ultraviolet" title="Ultraviolet">ultraviolet</a> <a href="/wiki/Solar_radiation" class="mw-redirect" title="Solar radiation">solar radiation</a>, permitting life on land.<sup id="cite_ref-Harrison_2002_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harrison_2002-160">[143]</a></sup> Other atmospheric functions important to life include transporting water vapor, providing useful gases, causing small <a href="/wiki/Meteor" class="mw-redirect" title="Meteor">meteors</a> to burn up before they strike the surface, and moderating temperature.<sup id="cite_ref-atmosphere_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-atmosphere-161">[144]</a></sup> This last phenomenon is known as the <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_effect" title="Greenhouse effect">greenhouse effect</a>: trace molecules within the atmosphere serve to capture <a href="/wiki/Thermal_energy" title="Thermal energy">thermal energy</a> emitted from the ground, thereby raising the average temperature. Water vapor, carbon dioxide, <a href="/wiki/Methane" title="Methane">methane</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nitrous_oxide" title="Nitrous oxide">nitrous oxide</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ozone" title="Ozone">ozone</a> are the primary <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas" title="Greenhouse gas">greenhouse gases</a> in the atmosphere. Without this heat-retention effect, the average surface temperature would be ?18&nbsp;°C, in contrast to the current +15&nbsp;°C,<sup id="cite_ref-Pidwirny2006_7_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pidwirny2006_7-162">[145]</a></sup> and life on Earth probably would not exist in its current form.<sup id="cite_ref-Narottam2008_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Narottam2008-163">[146]</a></sup> In May 2017, glints of light, seen as twinkling from an orbiting satellite a million miles away, were found to be <a href="/wiki/Reflection_(physics)" title="Reflection (physics)">reflected light</a> from <a href="/wiki/Ice_crystals" title="Ice crystals">ice crystals</a> in the atmosphere.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT-20170519_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20170519-164">[147]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-GRL-201760515_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GRL-201760515-165">[148]</a></sup></p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Weather_and_climate">Weather and climate</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: 
       <a href="/wiki/Weather" title="Weather">Weather</a> and 
       <a href="/wiki/Climate" title="Climate">Climate</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"> 
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px"> 
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Felix_from_ISS_03_sept_2007_1138Z.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Felix_from_ISS_03_sept_2007_1138Z.jpg/220px-Felix_from_ISS_03_sept_2007_1138Z.jpg" width="220" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Felix_from_ISS_03_sept_2007_1138Z.jpg/330px-Felix_from_ISS_03_sept_2007_1138Z.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Felix_from_ISS_03_sept_2007_1138Z.jpg/440px-Felix_from_ISS_03_sept_2007_1138Z.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2772" data-file-height="1890"></a>
         </div> 
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Felix" title="Hurricane Felix">Hurricane Felix</a> seen from low Earth orbit, September 2007
         </div> 
        </div>
