In many cultures it is a <a href="/wiki/Mother_goddess" title="Mother goddess">mother goddess</a> that is also the primary <a href="/wiki/Fertility_deity" class="mw-redirect" title="Fertility deity">fertility deity</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-:0_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-249">[229]</a></sup> and by the mid-20th century, the <a href="/wiki/Gaia_hypothesis" title="Gaia hypothesis">Gaia Principle</a> compared Earth's environments and life as a single self-regulating organism leading to broad stabilization of the conditions of habitability.<sup id="cite_ref-vanishing255_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vanishing255-250">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-J1972_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-J1972-251">[231]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-lovelock1974_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lovelock1974-252">[232]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Creation_myth" title="Creation myth">Creation myths</a> in many religions involve the creation of Earth by a supernatural <a href="/wiki/Deity" title="Deity">deity</a> or deities.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_249-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-249">[229]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Scientific investigation has resulted in several culturally transformative shifts in people's view of the planet. In the West, belief in a <a href="/wiki/Flat_Earth" title="Flat Earth">flat Earth</a><sup id="cite_ref-russell1997_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-russell1997-253">[233]</a></sup> was displaced by the idea of <a href="/wiki/Spherical_Earth" title="Spherical Earth">spherical Earth</a>, credited to <a href="/wiki/Pythagoras" title="Pythagoras">Pythagoras</a> in the 6th century BC.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[234]</a></sup> Earth was further believed to be <a href="/wiki/Geocentric_model" title="Geocentric model">the center of the universe</a> until the 16th century when scientists first theorized that it was <a href="/wiki/Heliocentrism" title="Heliocentrism">a moving object</a>, comparable to the other planets in the Solar System.<sup id="cite_ref-arnett20060716_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arnett20060716-255">[235]</a></sup> Due to the efforts of influential Christian scholars and clerics such as <a href="/wiki/James_Ussher" title="James Ussher">James Ussher</a>, who sought to determine the age of Earth through analysis of genealogies in Scripture, Westerners before the 19th century generally believed Earth to be a few thousand years old at most. It was only during the 19th century that geologists realized <a href="/wiki/Earth%27s_age" class="mw-redirect" title="Earth's age">Earth's age</a> was at least many millions of years.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[236]</a></sup></p> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/William_Thomson,_1st_Baron_Kelvin" title="William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin">Lord Kelvin</a> used <a href="/wiki/Thermodynamics" title="Thermodynamics">thermodynamics</a> to estimate the age of Earth to be between 20 million and 400&nbsp;million years in 1864, sparking a vigorous debate on the subject; it was only when radioactivity and <a href="/wiki/Radiometric_dating" title="Radiometric dating">radioactive dating</a> were discovered in the late 19th and early 20th centuries that a reliable mechanism for determining Earth's age was established, proving the planet to be billions of years old.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[237]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[238]</a></sup> The perception of Earth shifted again in the 20th century when humans first viewed it from orbit, and especially with photographs of Earth returned by the <a href="/wiki/Apollo_program" title="Apollo program">Apollo program</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[239]</a></sup></p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;"> 
       <ol class="references"> 
        <li id="cite_note-epoch-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-epoch_1-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">All astronomical quantities vary, both <a href="/wiki/Secular_phenomena" class="mw-redirect" title="Secular phenomena">secularly</a> and <a href="/wiki/Frequency" title="Frequency">periodically</a>. The quantities given are the values at the instant <a href="/wiki/J2000.0" class="mw-redirect" title="J2000.0">J2000.0</a> of the secular variation, ignoring all periodic variations.</span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-apsis-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-apsis_2-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-apsis_2-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">aphelion = <i>a</i> × (1 + <i>e</i>); perihelion = <i>a</i> × (1&nbsp;– <i>e</i>), where <i>a</i> is the semi-major axis and <i>e</i> is the eccentricity. The difference between Earth's perihelion and aphelion is 5 million kilometers.</span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-space_debris-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-space_debris_8-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-space_debris_8-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">As of 5 July 2016, the United States Strategic Command tracked a total of 17,729 artificial objects, mostly debris. See: <cite class="citation magazine"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://orbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov/quarterly-news/pdfs/odqnv20i3.pdf">"Orbital Debris Quarterly News"</a> <span style="font-size:85%;">(PDF)</span>. Vol.&nbsp;20 no.&nbsp;3. <a href="/wiki/NASA" title="NASA">NASA</a>. July 2016. p.&nbsp;8<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">10 October</span> 2016</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Orbital+Debris+Quarterly+News&amp;rft.pages=8&amp;rft.pub=NASA&amp;rft.date=2016-07&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Forbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov%2Fquarterly-news%2Fpdfs%2Fodqnv20i3.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEarth" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-surfacecover-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-surfacecover_18-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Due to natural fluctuations, ambiguities surrounding <a href="/wiki/Ice_shelf" title="Ice shelf">ice shelves</a>, and mapping conventions for <a href="/wiki/Vertical_datum" class="mw-redirect" title="Vertical datum">vertical datums</a>, exact values for land and ocean coverage are not meaningful. Based on data from the <a href="/wiki/Vector_Map" title="Vector Map">Vector Map</a> and <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.landcover.org/">Global Landcover</a> datasets, extreme values for coverage of lakes and streams are 0.6% and 1.0% of Earth's surface. The ice shields of <a href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">Antarctica</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a> are counted as land, even though much of the rock that supports them lies below sea level.</span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-sidereal_solar-31"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-sidereal_solar_31-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The number of solar days is one less than the number of <a href="/wiki/Sidereal_day" class="mw-redirect" title="Sidereal day">sidereal days</a> because the orbital motion of Earth around the Sun causes one additional revolution of the planet about its axis.</span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-45"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-45">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Including <i>eorþe</i>, <i>erþe</i>, <i>erde</i>, and <i>erthe</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-oedearth_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oedearth-44">[39]</a></sup></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-47"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-47">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">As in <i><a href="/wiki/Beowulf" title="Beowulf">Beowulf</a></i> (1531–33):<br> <i>Wearp ða wundelmæl&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;wrættum gebunden<br> yrre oretta,&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;þæt hit on <b>eorðan</b> læg,<br> stið ond stylecg.</i><sup id="cite_ref-oedearth_44-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oedearth-44">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-beo_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beo-46">[40]</a></sup><br> "He threw the artfully-wound sword so that it lay upon the <b>earth</b>, firm and sharp-edged."<sup id="cite_ref-beo_46-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-beo-46">[40]</a></sup></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-49"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-49">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">As in the Old English glosses of the <i><a href="/wiki/Lindisfarne_Gospels" title="Lindisfarne Gospels">Lindisfarne Gospels</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Luke_13" title="Luke 13">Luke 13</a>:7):<br> Succidite ergo illam ut quid etiam <b>terram</b> occupat: <i>hrendas</i> uel <i>scearfað forðon ðailca</i> uel <i>hia to huon uutedlice <b>eorðo</b> gionetað</i> uel <i>gemerras.</i><sup id="cite_ref-oedearth_44-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oedearth-44">[39]</a></sup><br> "Remove it. Why should it use up the <b>soil</b>?"<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[41]</a></sup></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-52">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">As in <a href="/wiki/%C3%86lfric_of_Eynsham" title="Ælfric of Eynsham">Ælfric</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Heptateuch" title="Heptateuch">Heptateuch</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Book_of_Genesis" title="Book of Genesis">Gen. 1</a>:10):<br> <i>Ond God gecygde ða drignysse <b>eorðan</b> ond ðære wætera gegaderunge he het sæ</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-oedearth_44-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oedearth-44">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[42]</a></sup><br> "And God called the dry land <b>Earth</b>; and the gathering together of the waters called he Seas."<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[43]</a></sup></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-54"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-54">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">As in the <a href="/wiki/Wessex_Gospels" title="Wessex Gospels">Wessex Gospels</a> (<a href="/wiki/Matthew_28" title="Matthew 28">Matt. 28</a>:18):<br> <i>Me is geseald ælc anweald on heofonan &amp; on <b>eorðan</b></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-oedearth_44-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oedearth-44">[39]</a></sup><br> "All authority in heaven and on <b>earth</b> has been given to me."<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[44]</a></sup></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-57"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-57">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">As in the <a href="/wiki/Codex_Junius" class="mw-redirect" title="Codex Junius">Codex Junius</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Genesis_A" title="Genesis A">Genesis</a></i> (112–16):<br> <i>her ærest gesceop&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ece drihten,<br> helm eallwihta,&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;heofon and <b>eorðan</b>,<br> rodor arærde&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and þis rume land<br> gestaþelode&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;strangum mihtum,<br> frea ælmihtig.</i><sup id="cite_ref-oedearth_44-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oedearth-44">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[45]</a></sup><br> "Here first with mighty power the Everlasting Lord, the Helm of all created things, Almighty King, made <b>earth</b> and heaven, raised up the sky and founded the spacious land."<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[46]</a></sup></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-59"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-59">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">As in <a href="/wiki/%C3%86lfric_of_Eynsham" title="Ælfric of Eynsham">Ælfric</a>'s <i>On the Seasons of the Year</i> <span class="nowrap">(Ch. 6,</span> §9):<br> <i>Seo <b>eorðe</b> stent on gelicnysse anre pinnhnyte, &amp; seo sunne glit onbutan be Godes gesetnysse.</i><sup id="cite_ref-oedearth_44-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oedearth-44">[39]</a></sup><br> "The <b>earth</b> can be compared to a pine cone, and the Sun glides around it by God's decree.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[47]</a></sup></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-109"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-109">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">If Earth were shrunk to the size of a <a href="/wiki/Billiard_ball" title="Billiard ball">billiard ball</a>, some areas of Earth such as large mountain ranges and oceanic trenches would feel like tiny imperfections, whereas much of the planet, including the <a href="/wiki/Great_Plains" title="Great Plains">Great Plains</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Abyssal_plain" title="Abyssal plain">abyssal plains</a>, would feel smoother.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[96]</a></sup></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-117"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-117">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Locally varies between 5 and 200&nbsp;km.</span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-118"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-118">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Locally varies between 5 and 70&nbsp;km.</span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-jaes41_3_379-129"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-jaes41_3_379_129-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Including the <a href="/wiki/Somali_Plate" title="Somali Plate">Somali Plate</a>, which is being formed out of the African Plate. See: <cite class="citation journal">Chorowicz, Jean (October 2005). "The East African rift system". <i><a href="/wiki/Journal_of_African_Earth_Sciences" title="Journal of African Earth Sciences">Journal of African Earth Sciences</a></i>. <b>43</b> (1–3): 379–410. <a href="/wiki/Bibcode" title="Bibcode">Bibcode</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2005JAfES..43..379C">2005JAfES..43..379C</a>. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1016%2Fj.jafrearsci.2005.07.019">10.1016/j.jafrearsci.2005.07.019</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+African+Earth+Sciences&amp;rft.atitle=The+East+African+rift+system&amp;rft.volume=43&amp;rft.issue=1%E2%80%933&amp;rft.pages=379-410&amp;rft.date=2005-10&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1016%2Fj.jafrearsci.2005.07.019&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F2005JAfES..43..379C&amp;rft.aulast=Chorowicz&amp;rft.aufirst=Jean&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEarth" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-trench_depth-148"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-trench_depth_148-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This is the measurement taken by the vessel <i><a href="/wiki/Kaik%C5%8D" class="mw-redirect" title="Kaik?">Kaik?</a></i> in March 1995 and is considered the most accurate measurement to date. See the <a href="/wiki/Challenger_Deep" title="Challenger Deep">Challenger Deep</a> article for more details.</span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Aoki-197"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Aoki_197-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The ultimate source of these figures, uses the term "seconds of UT1" instead of "seconds of mean solar time".—<cite class="citation journal">Aoki, S.; Kinoshita, H.; Guinot, B.; Kaplan, G. H.; McCarthy, D. D.; Seidelmann, P. K. (1982). "The new definition of universal time". <i>Astronomy and Astrophysics</i>. <b>105</b> (2): 359–61. <a href="/wiki/Bibcode" title="Bibcode">Bibcode</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1982A&amp;A...105..359A">1982A&amp;A...105..359A</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Astronomy+and+Astrophysics&amp;rft.atitle=The+new+definition+of+universal+time&amp;rft.volume=105&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=359-61&amp;rft.date=1982&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F1982A%26A...105..359A&amp;rft.aulast=Aoki&amp;rft.aufirst=S.&amp;rft.au=Kinoshita%2C+H.&amp;rft.au=Guinot%2C+B.&amp;rft.au=Kaplan%2C+G.+H.&amp;rft.au=McCarthy%2C+D.+D.&amp;rft.au=Seidelmann%2C+P.+K.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEarth" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-hill_radius-205"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-hill_radius_205-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">For Earth, the <a href="/wiki/Hill_radius" class="mw-redirect" title="Hill radius">Hill radius</a> is <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
            <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle R_{H}=a\left({\frac {m}{3M}}\right)^{\frac {1}{3}}}"> 
             <semantics> 
              <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
               <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"> 
                <msub> 
                 <mi>
                  R
                 </mi> 
                 <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
                  <mi>
                   H
                  </mi> 
                 </mrow> 
                </msub> 
                <mo>
                 =
                </mo> 
                <mi>
                 a
                </mi> 
                <msup> 
                 <mrow> 
                  <mo>
                   (
                  </mo> 
                  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
                   <mfrac> 
                    <mi>
                     m
                    </mi> 
                    <mrow> 
                     <mn>
                      3
                     </mn> 
                     <mi>
                      M
                     </mi> 
                    </mrow> 
                   </mfrac> 
                  </mrow> 
                  <mo>
                   )
                  </mo> 
                 </mrow> 
                 <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
                  <mfrac> 
                   <mn>
                    1
                   </mn> 
                   <mn>
                    3
                   </mn> 
                  </mfrac> 
                 </mrow> 
                </msup> 
               </mstyle> 
              </mrow> 
              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
               {\displaystyle R_{H}=a\left({\frac {m}{3M}}\right)^{\frac {1}{3}}}
              </annotation> 
             </semantics> 
            </math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/596f8baf206a81478afd4194b44138715dc1a05c" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -2.005ex; width:16.736ex; height:6.009ex;" alt="R_{H}=a\left({\frac {m}{3M}}\right)^{\frac {1}{3}}"></span>, where <i>m</i> is the mass of Earth, <i>a</i> is an astronomical unit, and <i>M</i> is the mass of the Sun. So the radius in AU is about <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;">
            <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle \left({\frac {1}{3\cdot 332,946}}\right)^{\frac {1}{3}}=0.01}">

              <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
               <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"> 
                <msup> 
                 <mrow> 
                  <mo>
                   (
                  </mo> 
                  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
                   <mfrac> 
                    <mn>
                     1
                    </mn> 
                    <mrow> 
                     <mn>
                      3
                     </mn> 
                     <mo>
                      ?
                      <!-- ? -->
                     </mo> 
                     <mn>
                      332
                     </mn> 
                     <mo>
                      ,
                     </mo> 
                     <mn>
                      946
                     </mn> 
                    </mrow> 
                   </mfrac> 
                  </mrow> 
                  <mo>
                   )
                  </mo> 
                 </mrow> 
                 <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD"> 
                  <mfrac>

                    1
                   </mn> 
                   <mn>
                    3
                   </mn> 
                  </mfrac> 
                 </mrow> 
                </msup> 
                <mo>
                 =
                </mo> 
                <mn>
                 0.01
                </mn> 
               </mstyle> 
              </mrow> 
              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
               {\displaystyle \left({\frac {1}{3\cdot 332,946}}\right)^{\frac {1}{3}}=0.01}
              </annotation> 
             </semantics> 
            </math></span><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7ab5412b4744a2163206868fe8ec2726455c4785" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -2.505ex; width:24.076ex; height:7.176ex;" alt="\left({\frac {1}{3\cdot 332,946}}\right)^{\frac {1}{3}}=0.01"></span>.</span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-solar_energy-210"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-solar_energy_210-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Aphelion is 103.4% of the distance to perihelion. Due to the inverse square law, the radiation at perihelion is about 106.9% the energy at aphelion.</span></li> 
       </ol> 
      </div>

        <li id="cite_note-VSOP87-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-VSOP87_3-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-VSOP87_3-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Simon, J.L.; Bretagnon, P.; Chapront, J.; Chapront-Touzé, M.; Francou, G.; Laskar, J. (February 1994). "Numerical expressions for precession formulae and mean elements for the Moon and planets". <i>Astronomy and Astrophysics</i>. <b>282</b> (2): 663–83. <a href="/wiki/Bibcode" title="Bibcode">Bibcode</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1994A&amp;A...282..663S">1994A&amp;A...282..663S</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Astronomy+and+Astrophysics&amp;rft.atitle=Numerical+expressions+for+precession+formulae+and+mean+elements+for+the+Moon+and+planets&amp;rft.volume=282&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=663-83&amp;rft.date=1994-02&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F1994A%26A...282..663S&amp;rft.aulast=Simon&amp;rft.aufirst=J.L.&amp;rft.au=Bretagnon%2C+P.&amp;rft.au=Chapront%2C+J.&amp;rft.au=Chapront-Touz%C3%A9%2C+M.&amp;rft.au=Francou%2C+G.&amp;rft.au=Laskar%2C+J.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEarth" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-IERS-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-IERS_4-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IERS_4-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IERS_4-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IERS_4-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IERS_4-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Staff (7 August 2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://hpiers.obspm.fr/eop-pc/models/constants.html">"Useful Constants"</a>. <a href="/wiki/International_Earth_Rotation_and_Reference_Systems_Service" title="International Earth Rotation and Reference Systems Service">International Earth Rotation and Reference Systems Service</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">23 September</span> 2008</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Useful+Constants&amp;rft.pub=International+Earth+Rotation+and+Reference+Systems+Service&amp;rft.date=2007-08-07&amp;rft.au=Staff&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fhpiers.obspm.fr%2Feop-pc%2Fmodels%2Fconstants.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEarth" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-earth_fact_sheet-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-8"><sup><i><b>i</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-9"><sup><i><b>j</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-10"><sup><i><b>k</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-earth_fact_sheet_5-11"><sup><i><b>l</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Williams, David R. (1 September 2004). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/factsheet/earthfact.html">"Earth Fact Sheet"</a>. NASA<span class="reference-accessdate">.         <li id="cite_note-circ-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-circ_15-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Earth's <a href="/wiki/Circumference" title="Circumference">circumference</a> is almost exactly 40,000 km because the metre was calibrated on this measurement—more specifically, 1/10-millionth of the distance between the poles and the equator.</span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-Pidwirny_2006_8-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Pidwirny_2006_8_16-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Pidwirny_2006_8_16-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Pidwirny_2006_8_16-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Pidwirny, Michael (2 February 2006). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.physicalgeography.net/fundamentals/8o.html">"Surface area of our planet covered by oceans and continents.(Table 8o-1)"</a>.         <li id="cite_note-Allen296-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Allen296_22-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Allen, Clabon Walter; Cox, Arthur N.         <li id="cite_note-Book-Biology-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Book-Biology_37-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Kunin, W.E.; Gaston, Kevin, eds.         <li id="cite_note-age_earth1-64"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-age_earth1_64-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See:</span> 
         <ul> 
          <li><span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Dalrymple, G.B. (1991). <i>The Age of the Earth</i>.           <li><cite class="citation journal">Dalrymple, G.          </ul> </li>

        <li id="cite_note-PNAS-2017-89"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-PNAS-2017_89-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Schopf, J.         <li id="cite_note-sun_future_schroder-100"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-sun_future_schroder_100-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-sun_future_schroder_100-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Schröder, K.-P.; Connon Smith, Robert (2008).                <tr> 
                <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="text-align:center;;width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Planet" title="Planet">Planets</a></th> 
                <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"> 
                 <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
                  <ul> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Terrestrial_planet" title="Terrestrial planet">Terrestrial planets</a> 
                    <ul> 
                     <li><a href="/wiki/Mercury_(planet)" title="Mercury (planet)">Mercury</a></li> 
                     <li><a href="/wiki/Venus" title="Venus">Venus</a></li>

                     <li><a href="/wiki/Jupiter" title="Jupiter">Jupiter</a></li>

                     <li><a href="/wiki/Uranus" title="Uranus">Uranus</a></li> 
                     <li><a href="/wiki/Neptune" title="Neptune">Neptune</a></li> 
                    </ul> </li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Dwarf_planet" title="Dwarf planet">Dwarf planets</a> 
                    <ul>

               <tr> 
                <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Included</th> 
                <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"> 
                 <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
                  <a class="mw-selflink selflink">Earth</a>&nbsp;
                  <span style="font-size: 120%;">?</span> 
                  <a href="/wiki/Solar_System" title="Solar System">Solar System</a>&nbsp;
                  <span style="font-size: 120%;">?</span> 
                  <a href="/wiki/Local_Interstellar_Cloud" title="Local Interstellar Cloud">Local Interstellar Cloud</a>&nbsp;
                  <span style="font-size: 120%;">?</span> 
                  <a href="/wiki/Local_Bubble" title="Local Bubble">Local Bubble</a>&nbsp;
                  <span style="font-size: 120%;">?</span> 
                  <a href="/wiki/Gould_Belt" title="Gould Belt">Gould Belt</a>&nbsp;
                  <span style="font-size: 120%;">?</span> 
                  <a href="/wiki/Orion_Arm" title="Orion Arm">Orion Arm</a>&nbsp;
                  <span style="font-size: 120%;">?</span> 
                  <a href="/wiki/Milky_Way" title="Milky Way">Milky Way</a>&nbsp;
                  <span style="font-size: 120%;">?</span> 
                  <a href="/wiki/Satellite_galaxies_of_the_Milky_Way" title="Satellite galaxies of the Milky Way">Milky Way subgroup</a>&nbsp;
                  <span style="font-size: 120%;">?</span> 
                  <a href="/wiki/Local_Group" title="Local Group">Local Group</a>&nbsp;
                  <span style="font-size: 120%;">?</span> 
                  <a href="/wiki/Virgo_Supercluster" title="Virgo Supercluster">Virgo Supercluster</a>&nbsp;
                  <span style="font-size: 120%;">?</span> 
                  <a href="/wiki/Laniakea_Supercluster" title="Laniakea Supercluster">Laniakea Supercluster</a>&nbsp;
                  <span style="font-size: 120%;">?</span> 
                  <a href="/wiki/Observable_universe" title="Observable universe">Observable universe</a>&nbsp;
                  <span style="font-size: 120%;">?</span> 
                  <a href="/wiki/Universe" title="Universe">Universe</a>
                  <br> 
                  <span style="font-size:90%;">Each arrow (<span style="font-size: 120%;">?</span>) may be read as "within" or "part of".</span>
                 </div> </td> 
               </tr>

   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Eclipse</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
      Jump to: 
     <a href="#mw-head">navigation</a>, 
     <a href="#p-search">search</a> 
    </div> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       For other uses, see 
       <a href="/wiki/Eclipse_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Eclipse (disambiguation)">Eclipse (disambiguation)</a> and 
       <a href="/wiki/Total_Eclipse_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Total Eclipse (disambiguation)">Total Eclipse (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg/250px-Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg" width="250" height="246" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg/375px-Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg/500px-Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3543" data-file-height="3489"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Solar_eclipse_1999_4_NR.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Totality during the 1999 solar eclipse. 
         <a href="/wiki/Solar_prominence" title="Solar prominence">Solar prominences</a> can be seen along the limb (in red) as well as extensive 
         <a href="/wiki/Corona" title="Corona">coronal</a> filaments.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>An <b>eclipse</b> is an <a href="/wiki/Astronomical_event" class="mw-redirect" title="Astronomical event">astronomical event</a> that occurs when an <a href="/wiki/Astronomical_object" title="Astronomical object">astronomical object</a> is temporarily obscured, either by passing into the shadow of another body or by having another body pass between it and the viewer. This alignment of three celestial objects is known as a <a href="/wiki/Syzygy_(astronomy)" title="Syzygy (astronomy)">syzygy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> Apart from syzygy, the term eclipse is also used when a spacecraft reaches a position where it can observe two celestial bodies so aligned. An eclipse is the result of either an <a href="/wiki/Occultation" title="Occultation">occultation</a> (completely hidden) or a <a href="/wiki/Transit_(astronomy)" title="Transit (astronomy)">transit</a> (partially hidden).</p> 
      <p>The term eclipse is most often used to describe either a <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse" title="Solar eclipse">solar eclipse</a>, when the Moon's shadow crosses the Earth's surface, or a <a href="/wiki/Lunar_eclipse" title="Lunar eclipse">lunar eclipse</a>, when the Moon moves into the Earth's shadow. However, it can also refer to such events beyond the Earth–Moon system: for example, a planet moving into the shadow cast by one of its moons, a moon passing into the shadow cast by its host planet, or a moon passing into the shadow of another moon. A <a href="/wiki/Binary_star" title="Binary star">binary star</a> system can also produce eclipses if the plane of the orbit of its constituent stars intersects the observer's position.</p> 
      <p>For the special cases of solar and lunar eclipses, these only happen during an "<a href="/wiki/Eclipse_season" title="Eclipse season">eclipse season</a>", the two times of each year when the plane of the Earth's orbit around the Sun crosses with the plane of the Moon's orbit around the Earth. The <a href="/wiki/Solar_eclipse#Types" title="Solar eclipse">type of solar eclipse</a> that happens during each season (whether total, annular, hybrid, or partial) depends on <a href="/wiki/Apparent_size" class="mw-redirect" title="Apparent size">apparent sizes</a> of the Sun and Moon. If the orbit of the Earth around the Sun, and the Moon's orbit around the Earth were both in the same plane with each other, then eclipses would happen each and every month. There would be a lunar eclipse at every full moon, and a solar eclipse at every new moon. And if both orbits were perfectly circular, then each solar eclipse would be the same type every month. It is because of the non-planar and non-circular differences that eclipses are not a common event. Lunar eclipses can be viewed from the entire nightside half of the Earth. But solar eclipses, particularly a total eclipse, as occurring at any one particular point on the Earth's surface, is a rare event that can span many decades from one to the next.</p> 
      <p></p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc"> 
       <div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr" xml:lang="en"> 
        <h2>Contents</h2> 
       </div>

        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Eclipse_cycles"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Eclipse cycles</span></a></li> 
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Earth–Moon_system"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Earth–Moon system</span></a> 
         <ul>

         <ul> 
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-9"><a href="#Gas_giants"><span class="tocnumber">5.1</span> <span class="toctext">Gas giants</span></a></li> 
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-10"><a href="#Mars"><span class="tocnumber">5.2</span> <span class="toctext">Mars</span></a></li> 
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-11"><a href="#Pluto"><span class="tocnumber">5.3</span> <span class="toctext">Pluto</span></a></li>

         </ul> </li> 
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-13"><a href="#Eclipsing_binaries"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Eclipsing binaries</span></a></li>
