              <track src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=TimedText:Frase_de_Neil_Armstrong.ogg.pt-br.srt&amp;action=raw&amp;ctype=text%2Fx-srt" kind="subtitles" type="text/x-srt" srclang="pt-br" label="português do Brasil (pt-br) subtitles" data-mwtitle="TimedText:Frase_de_Neil_Armstrong.ogg.pt-br.srt" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-dir="ltr"> 
              <track src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=TimedText:Frase_de_Neil_Armstrong.ogg.pt.srt&amp;action=raw&amp;ctype=text%2Fx-srt" kind="subtitles" type="text/x-srt" srclang="pt" label="português (pt) subtitles" data-mwtitle="TimedText:Frase_de_Neil_Armstrong.ogg.pt.srt" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-dir="ltr"> 
              <track src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=TimedText:Frase_de_Neil_Armstrong.ogg.ta.srt&amp;action=raw&amp;ctype=text%2Fx-srt" kind="subtitles" type="text/x-srt" srclang="ta" label="????? (ta) subtitles" data-mwtitle="TimedText:Frase_de_Neil_Armstrong.ogg.ta.srt" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-dir="ltr"> 
              <track src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=TimedText:Frase_de_Neil_Armstrong.ogg.tl.srt&amp;action=raw&amp;ctype=text%2Fx-srt" kind="subtitles" type="text/x-srt" srclang="tl" label="Tagalog (tl) subtitles" data-mwtitle="TimedText:Frase_de_Neil_Armstrong.ogg.tl.srt" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-dir="ltr">
             </audio>
            </div> 
           </div> 
           <div class="description" style="padding:2px 0 0 0"></div> 
          </div> </td> 
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td colspan="2" class="mbox-text" style="line-height:1.1em"> 
          <hr> <span><i>Problems playing this file? See <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:Media help">media help</a>.</i></span></td> 
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Neil_Armstrong" title="Neil Armstrong">Neil Armstrong</a> became the first person to walk on the Moon as the commander of the American mission <a href="/wiki/Apollo_11" title="Apollo 11">Apollo 11</a> by first setting foot on the Moon at 02:56&nbsp;UTC on 21 July 1969.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[179]</a></sup> An estimated 500&nbsp;million people worldwide watched the transmission by the <a href="/wiki/Apollo_TV_camera" title="Apollo TV camera">Apollo TV camera</a>, the largest television audience for a live broadcast at that time.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[180]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[181]</a></sup> The Apollo missions 11 to 17 (except <a href="/wiki/Apollo_13" title="Apollo 13">Apollo 13</a>, which aborted its planned lunar landing) returned 380.05 kilograms (837.87&nbsp;lb) of lunar rock and soil in 2,196 separate samples.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[182]</a></sup> The American <a href="/wiki/Moon_landing" title="Moon landing">Moon landing</a> and return was enabled by considerable technological advances in the early 1960s, in domains such as <a href="/wiki/Ablation" title="Ablation">ablation</a> chemistry, <a href="/wiki/Software_engineering" title="Software engineering">software engineering</a> and <a href="/wiki/Atmospheric_re-entry" class="mw-redirect" title="Atmospheric re-entry">atmospheric re-entry</a> technology, and by highly competent management of the enormous technical undertaking.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[183]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[184]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Scientific instrument packages were installed on the lunar surface during all the Apollo landings. Long-lived <a href="/wiki/Apollo_Lunar_Surface_Experiments_Package" title="Apollo Lunar Surface Experiments Package">instrument stations</a>, including heat flow probes, <a href="/wiki/Seismometer" title="Seismometer">seismometers</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Magnetometer" title="Magnetometer">magnetometers</a>, were installed at the <a href="/wiki/Apollo_12" title="Apollo 12">Apollo 12</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apollo_14" title="Apollo 14">14</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apollo_15" title="Apollo 15">15</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apollo_16" title="Apollo 16">16</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Apollo_17" title="Apollo 17">17</a> landing sites. Direct transmission of data to Earth concluded in late 1977 due to budgetary considerations,<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[185]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[186]</a></sup> but as the stations' <a href="/wiki/Lunar_laser_ranging_experiment" class="mw-redirect" title="Lunar laser ranging experiment">lunar laser ranging</a> corner-cube retroreflector arrays are passive instruments, they are still being used. Ranging to the stations is routinely performed from Earth-based stations with an accuracy of a few centimetres, and data from this experiment are being used to place constraints on the size of the lunar core.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[187]</a></sup></p> 
      <h5><span id="1980s.E2.80.932000"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1980s–2000">1980s–2000</span></h5> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Moon_Crescent_-_False_Color_Mosaic.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Moon_Crescent_-_False_Color_Mosaic.jpg/200px-Moon_Crescent_-_False_Color_Mosaic.jpg" width="200" height="224" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Moon_Crescent_-_False_Color_Mosaic.jpg/300px-Moon_Crescent_-_False_Color_Mosaic.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Moon_Crescent_-_False_Color_Mosaic.jpg/400px-Moon_Crescent_-_False_Color_Mosaic.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2600" data-file-height="2910"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Moon_Crescent_-_False_Color_Mosaic.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> An 
         <a href="/wiki/False-color" class="mw-redirect" title="False-color">artificially</a> coloured mosaic constructed from a series of 53 images taken through three 
         <a href="/wiki/Filter_(optics)" class="mw-redirect" title="Filter (optics)">spectral filters</a> by 
         <i>Galileo'&nbsp;</i>s imaging system as the spacecraft flew over the northern regions of the Moon on 7 December 1992.
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>After the first Moon race there were years of near quietude but starting in the 1990s, many more countries have become involved in direct exploration of the Moon. In 1990, Japan became the third country to place a spacecraft into lunar orbit with its <i><a href="/wiki/Hiten" title="Hiten">Hiten</a></i> spacecraft. The spacecraft released a smaller probe, <i>Hagoromo</i>, in lunar orbit, but the transmitter failed, preventing further scientific use of the mission.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[188]</a></sup> In 1994, the U.S. sent the joint Defense Department/NASA spacecraft <i><a href="/wiki/Clementine_(spacecraft)" title="Clementine (spacecraft)">Clementine</a></i> to lunar orbit. This mission obtained the first near-global topographic map of the Moon, and the first global <a href="/wiki/Multi-spectral_image" class="mw-redirect" title="Multi-spectral image">multispectral</a> images of the lunar surface.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[189]</a></sup> This was followed in 1998 by the <i><a href="/wiki/Lunar_Prospector" title="Lunar Prospector">Lunar Prospector</a></i> mission, whose instruments indicated the presence of excess hydrogen at the lunar poles, which is likely to have been caused by the presence of water ice in the upper few meters of the regolith within permanently shadowed craters.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[190]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>India, Japan, China, the United States, and the <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a> each sent lunar orbiters, and especially <a href="/wiki/ISRO" class="mw-redirect" title="ISRO">ISRO</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan-1" title="Chandrayaan-1">Chandrayaan-1</a></i> has contributed to confirming the discovery of <a href="/wiki/Lunar_water" title="Lunar water">lunar water ice</a> in permanently shadowed craters at the poles and bound into the lunar <a href="/wiki/Regolith" title="Regolith">regolith</a>. The post-Apollo era has also seen two <a href="/wiki/Rover_(space_exploration)" title="Rover (space exploration)">rover</a> missions: the final Soviet <a href="/wiki/Lunokhod" class="mw-redirect" title="Lunokhod">Lunokhod</a> mission in 1973, and China's ongoing <a href="/wiki/Chang%27e_3" title="Chang'e 3">Chang'e 3</a> mission, which deployed its <a href="/wiki/Yutu_(rover)" title="Yutu (rover)">Yutu rover</a> on 14 December 2013. The Moon remains, under the <a href="/wiki/Outer_Space_Treaty" title="Outer Space Treaty">Outer Space Treaty</a>, free to all nations to explore for peaceful purposes.</p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="21st_century">21st century</span></h4> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mooncolony.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Mooncolony.jpg/220px-Mooncolony.jpg" width="220" height="141" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Mooncolony.jpg/330px-Mooncolony.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Mooncolony.jpg/440px-Mooncolony.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5192" data-file-height="3332"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mooncolony.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Artistic representation of a future Moon colony
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The European spacecraft <i><a href="/wiki/SMART-1" title="SMART-1">SMART-1</a></i>, the second <a href="/wiki/Ion_propulsion" class="mw-redirect" title="Ion propulsion">ion-propelled</a> spacecraft, was in lunar orbit from 15 November 2004 until its lunar impact on 3 September 2006, and made the first detailed survey of chemical elements on the lunar surface.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[191]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>The ambitious <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Lunar_Exploration_Program" title="Chinese Lunar Exploration Program">Chinese Lunar Exploration Program</a> began with <i><a href="/wiki/Chang%27e_1" title="Chang'e 1">Chang'e 1</a></i>, which successfully orbited the Moon from 5 November 2007 until its controlled lunar impact on 1 March 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-xinhua_20090301_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-xinhua_20090301-205">[192]</a></sup> It obtained a full image map of the Moon. <i><a href="/wiki/Chang%27e_2" title="Chang'e 2">Chang'e 2</a></i>, beginning in October 2010, reached the Moon more quickly, mapped the Moon at a higher resolution over an eight-month period, then left lunar orbit for an extended stay at the Earth–Sun L2 <a href="/wiki/Lagrangian_point" title="Lagrangian point">Lagrangian point</a>, before finally performing a flyby of asteroid <a href="/wiki/4179_Toutatis" title="4179 Toutatis">4179 Toutatis</a> on 13 December 2012, and then heading off into deep space. On 14 December 2013, <i><a href="/wiki/Chang%27e_3" title="Chang'e 3">Chang'e 3</a></i> landed a lunar <a href="/wiki/Lander_(spacecraft)" title="Lander (spacecraft)">lander</a> onto the Moon's surface, which in turn deployed a <a href="/wiki/Lunar_rover" title="Lunar rover">lunar rover</a>, named <i>Yutu</i> (Chinese: ??; literally "Jade Rabbit"). This was the first lunar <a href="/wiki/Soft_landing_(rocketry)" title="Soft landing (rocketry)">soft landing</a> since <i><a href="/wiki/Luna_24" title="Luna 24">Luna 24</a></i> in 1976, and the first lunar rover mission since <i><a href="/wiki/Lunokhod_2" title="Lunokhod 2">Lunokhod 2</a></i> in 1973. China intends to launch another rover mission (<i><a href="/wiki/Chang%27e_4" title="Chang'e 4">Chang'e 4</a></i>) before 2020, followed by a <a href="/wiki/Sample_return_mission" class="mw-redirect" title="Sample return mission">sample return mission</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Chang%27e_5" title="Chang'e 5">Chang'e 5</a></i>) soon after.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[193]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Between 4 October 2007 and 10 June 2009, the <a href="/wiki/Japan_Aerospace_Exploration_Agency" class="mw-redirect" title="Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency">Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/SELENE" title="SELENE">Kaguya</a> (Selene)</i> mission, a lunar orbiter fitted with a <a href="/wiki/High-definition_video" title="High-definition video">high-definition video</a> camera, and two small radio-transmitter satellites, obtained lunar geophysics data and took the first high-definition movies from beyond Earth orbit.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[194]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[195]</a></sup> India's first lunar mission, <i><a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan-1" title="Chandrayaan-1">Chandrayaan I</a></i>, orbited from 8 November 2008 until loss of contact on 27 August 2009, creating a high resolution chemical, mineralogical and photo-geological map of the lunar surface, and confirming the presence of water molecules in lunar soil.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[196]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Indian_Space_Research_Organisation" title="Indian Space Research Organisation">Indian Space Research Organisation</a> planned to launch <i><a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Chandrayaan II">Chandrayaan II</a></i> in 2013, which would have included a Russian robotic lunar rover.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[197]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[198]</a></sup> However, the failure of Russia's <i><a href="/wiki/Fobos-Grunt" title="Fobos-Grunt">Fobos-Grunt</a></i> mission has delayed this project.</p> 
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:184px;max-width:184px"> 
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:182px;max-width:182px"> 
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Copernicus_central_peaks.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Copernicus_central_peaks.png/180px-Copernicus_central_peaks.png" width="180" height="180" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Copernicus_central_peaks.png/270px-Copernicus_central_peaks.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Copernicus_central_peaks.png/360px-Copernicus_central_peaks.png 2x" data-file-width="920" data-file-height="920"></a>
         </div> 
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Copernicus_(lunar_crater)" title="Copernicus (lunar crater)">Copernicus</a>'s central peaks as observed by the 
          <a href="/wiki/Lunar_Reconnaissance_Orbiter" title="Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter">LRO</a>, 2012
         </div> 
        </div> 
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:182px;max-width:182px"> 
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ina_(LRO).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Ina_%28LRO%29.jpg/180px-Ina_%28LRO%29.jpg" width="180" height="201" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Ina_%28LRO%29.jpg/270px-Ina_%28LRO%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Ina_%28LRO%29.jpg/360px-Ina_%28LRO%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3140" data-file-height="3500"></a>
         </div> 
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          The 
          <a href="/wiki/Ina_(crater)" title="Ina (crater)">Ina</a> formation, 2009
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The U.S. co-launched the <i><a href="/wiki/Lunar_Reconnaissance_Orbiter" title="Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter">Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter</a></i> (LRO) and the <i><a href="/wiki/LCROSS" title="LCROSS">LCROSS</a></i> impactor and follow-up observation orbiter on 18 June 2009; <i>LCROSS</i> completed its mission by making a planned and widely observed impact in the crater <a href="/wiki/Cabeus_(crater)" title="Cabeus (crater)">Cabeus</a> on 9 October 2009,<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[199]</a></sup> whereas <i>LRO</i> is currently in operation, obtaining precise lunar <a href="/wiki/Altimetry" class="mw-redirect" title="Altimetry">altimetry</a> and high-resolution imagery. In November 2011, the LRO passed over the large and bright <a href="/wiki/Aristarchus_(crater)" title="Aristarchus (crater)">Aristarchus crater</a>. NASA released photos of the crater on 25 December 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[200]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>Two <a href="/wiki/NASA" title="NASA">NASA</a> <a href="/wiki/Gravity_Recovery_and_Interior_Laboratory" title="Gravity Recovery and Interior Laboratory">GRAIL</a> spacecraft began orbiting the Moon around 1 January 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[201]</a></sup> on a mission to learn more about the Moon's internal structure. NASA's <i><a href="/wiki/Lunar_Atmosphere_and_Dust_Environment_Explorer" title="Lunar Atmosphere and Dust Environment Explorer">LADEE</a></i> probe, designed to study the lunar <a href="/wiki/Exosphere" title="Exosphere">exosphere</a>, achieved orbit on 6 October 2013.</p> 
      <p>Upcoming lunar missions include Russia's <i><a href="/wiki/Luna-Glob" title="Luna-Glob">Luna-Glob</a></i>: an unmanned lander with a set of seismometers, and an orbiter based on its failed Martian <i><a href="/wiki/Fobos-Grunt" title="Fobos-Grunt">Fobos-Grunt</a></i> mission.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[202]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[203]</a></sup> Privately funded lunar exploration has been promoted by the <a href="/wiki/Google_Lunar_X_Prize" title="Google Lunar X Prize">Google Lunar X Prize</a>, announced 13 September 2007, which offers US$20&nbsp;million to anyone who can land a robotic rover on the Moon and meet other specified criteria.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[204]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Shackleton_Energy_Company" title="Shackleton Energy Company">Shackleton Energy Company</a> is building a program to establish operations on the south pole of the Moon to harvest water and supply their <a href="/wiki/Propellant_Depot" class="mw-redirect" title="Propellant Depot">Propellant Depots</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[205]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>NASA began to <a href="/wiki/Vision_for_Space_Exploration" title="Vision for Space Exploration">plan to resume manned missions</a> following the call by U.S. President <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> on 14 January 2004 for a manned mission to the Moon by 2019 and the construction of a lunar base by 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[206]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Constellation_program" title="Constellation program">Constellation program</a> was funded and construction and testing begun on a <a href="/wiki/Orion_(Constellation_program)" class="mw-redirect" title="Orion (Constellation program)">manned spacecraft</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ares_(rocket)" title="Ares (rocket)">launch vehicle</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[207]</a></sup> and design studies for a lunar base.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[208]</a></sup> However, that program has been cancelled in favor of a manned asteroid landing by 2025 and a manned <a href="/wiki/Mars" title="Mars">Mars</a> orbit by 2035.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[209]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> has also expressed its hope to send a manned mission to the Moon by 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[210]</a></sup></p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Planned_commercial_missions">Planned commercial missions</span></h4> 
      <p>In 2007, the X Prize Foundation together with Google launched the Google Lunar X Prize to encourage commercial endeavors to the Moon. A prize of $20 million will be awarded to the first private venture to get to the moon with a robotic lander by the end of March 2018, with additional prizes worth $10 million for further milestones.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[211]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-https://www.space.com_2017-09-25_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-https://www.space.com_2017-09-25-225">[212]</a></sup> As of August 2016, 16 teams are participating in the competition.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[213]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>In August 2016, the US government granted permission to US-based start-up Moon Express to land on the Moon.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-227">[214]</a></sup> This marked the first time that a private enterprise was given the right to do so. The decision is regarded as a precedent helping to define regulatory standards for deep-space commercial activity in the future, as thus far companies' operation had been restricted to being on or around Earth.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_227-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-227">[214]</a></sup></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Astronomy_from_the_Moon">Astronomy from the Moon</span></h2> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Earth_in_ultraviolet_from_the_Moon_(S72-40821).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Earth_in_ultraviolet_from_the_Moon_%28S72-40821%29.jpg/220px-Earth_in_ultraviolet_from_the_Moon_%28S72-40821%29.jpg" width="220" height="174" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Earth_in_ultraviolet_from_the_Moon_%28S72-40821%29.jpg/330px-Earth_in_ultraviolet_from_the_Moon_%28S72-40821%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Earth_in_ultraviolet_from_the_Moon_%28S72-40821%29.jpg/440px-Earth_in_ultraviolet_from_the_Moon_%28S72-40821%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1719" data-file-height="1362"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Earth_in_ultraviolet_from_the_Moon_(S72-40821).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> A false-color image of 
         <a href="/wiki/Earth" title="Earth">Earth</a> in 
         <a href="/wiki/Ultraviolet_light" class="mw-redirect" title="Ultraviolet light">ultraviolet light</a> taken from the surface of the Moon on the 
         <a href="/wiki/Apollo_16" title="Apollo 16">Apollo 16</a> mission. The day-side reflects a lot of UV light from the Sun, but the night-side shows faint bands of UV emission from the 
         <a href="/wiki/Aurora" title="Aurora">aurora</a> caused by charged particles.
         <sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[215]</a></sup>
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>For many years, the Moon has been recognized as an excellent site for telescopes.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[216]</a></sup> It is relatively nearby; <a href="/wiki/Astronomical_seeing" title="Astronomical seeing">astronomical seeing</a> is not a concern; certain craters near the poles are permanently dark and cold, and thus especially useful for <a href="/wiki/Infrared_telescope" title="Infrared telescope">infrared telescopes</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Radio_telescope" title="Radio telescope">radio telescopes</a> on the far side would be shielded from the radio chatter of Earth.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[217]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Lunar_soil" title="Lunar soil">lunar soil</a>, although it poses a problem for any moving parts of <a href="/wiki/Telescope" title="Telescope">telescopes</a>, can be mixed with <a href="/wiki/Carbon_nanotube" title="Carbon nanotube">carbon nanotubes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Epoxy" title="Epoxy">epoxies</a> and employed in the construction of mirrors up to 50 meters in diameter.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[218]</a></sup> A lunar <a href="/wiki/Zenith_telescope" title="Zenith telescope">zenith telescope</a> can be made cheaply with <a href="/wiki/Ionic_liquid" title="Ionic liquid">ionic liquid</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[219]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>In April 1972, the <a href="/wiki/Apollo_16" title="Apollo 16">Apollo 16</a> mission recorded various astronomical photos and spectra in ultraviolet with the <a href="/wiki/Far_Ultraviolet_Camera/Spectrograph" title="Far Ultraviolet Camera/Spectrograph">Far Ultraviolet Camera/Spectrograph</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[220]</a></sup></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_status">Legal status</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Space_law" title="Space law">Space law</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Although <i><a href="/wiki/Luna_program" class="mw-redirect" title="Luna program">Luna</a></i> landers scattered pennants of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> on the Moon, and <a href="/wiki/Lunar_Flag_Assembly" title="Lunar Flag Assembly">U.S. flags</a> were symbolically planted at their landing sites by the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Apollo_astronauts" title="List of Apollo astronauts">Apollo astronauts</a>, no nation claims ownership of any part of the Moon's surface.<sup id="cite_ref-unoosa_q6_234-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unoosa_q6-234">[221]</a></sup> Russia and the U.S. are party to the 1967 <a href="/wiki/Outer_Space_Treaty" title="Outer Space Treaty">Outer Space Treaty</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-unoosa_q4_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unoosa_q4-235">[222]</a></sup> which defines the Moon and all outer space as the "<a href="/wiki/Common_heritage_of_mankind" title="Common heritage of mankind">province of all mankind</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-unoosa_q6_234-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unoosa_q6-234">[221]</a></sup> This treaty also restricts the use of the Moon to peaceful purposes, explicitly banning military installations and <a href="/wiki/Weapons_of_mass_destruction" class="mw-redirect" title="Weapons of mass destruction">weapons of mass destruction</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-unoosa_q5_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unoosa_q5-236">[223]</a></sup> The 1979 <a href="/wiki/Moon_Treaty" title="Moon Treaty">Moon Agreement</a> was created to restrict the exploitation of the Moon's resources by any single nation, but as of 2014, it has been signed and ratified by only 16 nations, none of which engages in self-launched <a href="/wiki/Human_spaceflight" title="Human spaceflight">human space exploration</a> or has plans to do so.<sup id="cite_ref-unoosa_moon_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unoosa_moon-237">[224]</a></sup> Although several individuals have made <a href="/wiki/Extraterrestrial_real_estate" title="Extraterrestrial real estate">claims to the Moon</a> in whole or in part, none of these are considered credible.<sup id="cite_ref-unoosa_q7_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unoosa_q7-238">[225]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-iisl_2004_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iisl_2004-239">[226]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-iisl_2009_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iisl_2009-240">[227]</a></sup></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="In_culture">In culture</span></h2> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Moon-bonatti.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Moon-bonatti.png/220px-Moon-bonatti.png" width="220" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Moon-bonatti.png/330px-Moon-bonatti.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Moon-bonatti.png/440px-Moon-bonatti.png 2x" data-file-width="577" data-file-height="407"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Moon-bonatti.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Luna, the Moon, from a 1550 edition of 
         <a href="/wiki/Guido_Bonatti" title="Guido Bonatti">Guido Bonatti</a>'s 
         <i>Liber astronomiae</i>
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: 
       <a href="/wiki/Moon_in_fiction" title="Moon in fiction">Moon in fiction</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mythology">Mythology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: 
       <a href="/wiki/Lunar_deity" class="mw-redirect" title="Lunar deity">Lunar deity</a>, 
       <a href="/wiki/Selene" title="Selene">Selene</a>, 
       <a href="/wiki/Luna_(goddess)" title="Luna (goddess)">Luna (goddess)</a>, 
       <a href="/wiki/Man_in_the_Moon" title="Man in the Moon">Man in the Moon</a>, and 
       <a href="/wiki/Crescent" title="Crescent">Crescent</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Nuremberg_chronicles_f_76r_3.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Nuremberg_chronicles_f_76r_3.png/220px-Nuremberg_chronicles_f_76r_3.png" width="220" height="208" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Nuremberg_chronicles_f_76r_3.png/330px-Nuremberg_chronicles_f_76r_3.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b2/Nuremberg_chronicles_f_76r_3.png 2x" data-file-width="342" data-file-height="323"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Nuremberg_chronicles_f_76r_3.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> Sun and Moon with faces (1493 woodcut)
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>A 5,000-year-old rock carving at <a href="/wiki/Knowth" title="Knowth">Knowth</a>, Ireland, may represent the Moon, which would be the earliest depiction discovered.<sup id="cite_ref-spacetoday_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-spacetoday-241">[228]</a></sup> The contrast between the brighter highlands and the darker maria creates the patterns seen by different cultures as the <a href="/wiki/Man_in_the_Moon" title="Man in the Moon">Man in the Moon</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Moon_rabbit" title="Moon rabbit">rabbit</a> and the buffalo, among others. In many prehistoric and ancient cultures, the Moon was personified as <a href="/wiki/Lunar_deity" class="mw-redirect" title="Lunar deity">a deity</a> or other <a href="/wiki/Supernatural" title="Supernatural">supernatural</a> phenomenon, and <a href="/wiki/Moon_(astrology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Moon (astrology)">astrological views of the Moon</a> continue to be propagated today.</p> 
      <p>In <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_religion" title="Proto-Indo-European religion">Proto-Indo-European religion</a>, the moon was personified as the male god <a href="/wiki/Moon_deity" class="mw-redirect" title="Moon deity"><i>*Meh<sub>1</sub>not</i></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dexter1984_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dexter1984-242">[229]</a></sup> The ancient <a href="/wiki/Sumer" title="Sumer">Sumerians</a> believed that the moon was the god <a href="/wiki/Sin_(mythology)" title="Sin (mythology)">Nanna</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Nemet1998_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nemet1998-243">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BlackGreen1992_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BlackGreen1992-244">[231]</a></sup> who was the father of <a href="/wiki/Inanna" title="Inanna">Inanna</a>, the goddess of the planet <a href="/wiki/Venus" title="Venus">Venus</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Nemet1998_243-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nemet1998-243">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BlackGreen1992_244-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BlackGreen1992-244">[231]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Utu" title="Utu">Utu</a>, the god of the sun.<sup id="cite_ref-Nemet1998_243-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nemet1998-243">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BlackGreen1992_244-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BlackGreen1992-244">[231]</a></sup> Nanna was later known as Sîn,<sup id="cite_ref-BlackGreen1992_244-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BlackGreen1992-244">[231]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Nemet1998_243-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nemet1998-243">[230]</a></sup> and was particularly associated with magic and sorcery.<sup id="cite_ref-Nemet1998_243-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nemet1998-243">[230]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Greco-Roman_mythology" class="mw-redirect" title="Greco-Roman mythology">Greco-Roman mythology</a>, the Sun and the Moon are represented as male and female, respectively (<a href="/wiki/Helios" title="Helios">Helios/Sol</a> and <a href="/wiki/Selene" title="Selene">Selene/Luna</a>);<sup id="cite_ref-Dexter1984_242-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dexter1984-242">[229]</a></sup> this is a development unique to the eastern Mediterranean<sup id="cite_ref-Dexter1984_242-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dexter1984-242">[229]</a></sup> and traces of an earlier male moon god in the Greek tradition are preserved in the figure of <a href="/wiki/Menelaus" title="Menelaus">Menelaus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dexter1984_242-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dexter1984-242">[229]</a></sup></p> 
      <p>In Mesopotamian iconography, the <a href="/wiki/Crescent" title="Crescent">crescent</a> was the primary symbol of Nanna-Sîn.<sup id="cite_ref-BlackGreen1992_244-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BlackGreen1992-244">[231]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_art" title="Ancient Greek art">ancient Greek art</a>, the Moon goddess <a href="/wiki/Selene" title="Selene">Selene</a> was represented wearing a crescent on her headgear in an arrangement reminiscent of horns.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[232]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[233]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Star_and_crescent" title="Star and crescent">star and crescent</a> arrangement also goes back to the Bronze Age, representing either the Sun and Moon, or the Moon and planet Venus, in combination. It came to represent the goddess <a href="/wiki/Artemis" title="Artemis">Artemis</a> or <a href="/wiki/Hecate" title="Hecate">Hecate</a>, and via the patronage of Hecate came to be used as a symbol of <a href="/wiki/Byzantium" title="Byzantium">Byzantium</a>.</p> 
      <p>An iconographic tradition of representing Sun and Moon with faces developed in the late medieval period.</p> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Splitting_of_the_moon" title="Splitting of the moon">splitting of the moon</a> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">?????? ?????</span>?) is a miracle attributed to <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[234]</a></sup></p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Calendar">Calendar</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: 
       <a href="/wiki/Lunar_calendar" title="Lunar calendar">Lunar calendar</a>, 
       <a href="/wiki/Lunisolar_calendar" title="Lunisolar calendar">Lunisolar calendar</a>, 
       <a href="/wiki/Metonic_cycle" title="Metonic cycle">Metonic cycle</a>, 
       <a href="/wiki/Blue_moon" title="Blue moon">Blue moon</a>, and 
       <a href="/wiki/Movable_feast" class="mw-redirect" title="Movable feast">Movable feast</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The Moon's regular phases make it a very convenient timepiece, and the periods of its waxing and waning form the basis of many of the oldest calendars. <a href="/wiki/Tally_stick" title="Tally stick">Tally sticks</a>, notched bones dating as far back as 20–30,000 years ago, are believed by some to mark the phases of the Moon.<sup id="cite_ref-Marshack_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marshack-248">[235]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[236]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[237]</a></sup> The ~30-day month is an approximation of the <a href="/wiki/Lunar_cycle" class="mw-redirect" title="Lunar cycle">lunar cycle</a>. The English noun <i>month</i> and its cognates in other Germanic languages stem from Proto-Germanic <i>*m?n?th-</i>, which is connected to the above-mentioned Proto-Germanic <i>*m?n?n</i>, indicating the usage of a <a href="/wiki/Lunar_calendar" title="Lunar calendar">lunar calendar</a> among the <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic peoples</a> (<a href="/wiki/Germanic_calendar" title="Germanic calendar">Germanic calendar</a>) prior to the adoption of a <a href="/wiki/Solar_calendar" title="Solar calendar">solar calendar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-barnhart-and-germania_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-barnhart-and-germania-251">[238]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_language" title="Proto-Indo-European language">PIE root</a> of <i>moon</i>, *<i>méh<sub>1</sub>n?t</i>, derives from the PIE verbal root *<i>meh<sub>1</sub></i>-, "to measure", "indicat[ing] a functional conception of the moon, i.e. marker of the month" (<a href="/wiki/Cf." title="Cf.">cf.</a> the English words <i>measure</i> and <i>menstrual</i>),<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[239]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[240]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[241]</a></sup> and echoing the Moon's importance to many ancient cultures in measuring time (see <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> <i><span lang="la"><i>mensis</i></span></i> and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient Greek</a> <span lang="grc"><i>????</i></span> (<i>meis</i>) or <span lang="grc">???</span> (m?n), meaning "month").<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[242]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[243]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[244]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[245]</a></sup> Most historical calendars are <a href="/wiki/Lunisolar_calendar" title="Lunisolar calendar">lunisolar</a>. The 7th-century <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Islamic calendar</a> is an exceptional example of a purely <a href="/wiki/Lunar_calendar" title="Lunar calendar">lunar calendar</a>. Months are traditionally determined by the visual sighting of the <a href="/wiki/Hilal_(crescent_moon)" title="Hilal (crescent moon)">hilal</a>, or earliest crescent moon, over the horizon.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[246]</a></sup></p> 
      <div class="thumb tright"> 
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:MaslowskiStanislaw.WschodKsiezyca.1884.ws.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/MaslowskiStanislaw.WschodKsiezyca.1884.ws.jpg/220px-MaslowskiStanislaw.WschodKsiezyca.1884.ws.jpg" width="220" height="123" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/MaslowskiStanislaw.WschodKsiezyca.1884.ws.jpg/330px-MaslowskiStanislaw.WschodKsiezyca.1884.ws.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/MaslowskiStanislaw.WschodKsiezyca.1884.ws.jpg/440px-MaslowskiStanislaw.WschodKsiezyca.1884.ws.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="446"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:MaslowskiStanislaw.WschodKsiezyca.1884.ws.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div> "Moonrise", 1884, picture by 
         <a href="/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_Mas%C5%82owski" title="Stanis?aw Mas?owski">Stanis?aw Mas?owski</a> (
         <a href="/wiki/National_Museum,_Krak%C3%B3w" title="National Museum, Kraków">National Museum, Kraków</a>, Gallery of 
         <a href="/wiki/Sukiennice_Museum" title="Sukiennice Museum">Sukiennice Museum</a>)
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Lunacy">Lunacy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: 
       <a href="/wiki/Lunar_effect" title="Lunar effect">Lunar effect</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The Moon has long been associated with insanity and irrationality; the words <i>lunacy</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Lunatic" title="Lunatic">lunatic</a></i> (popular shortening <i>loony</i>) are derived from the Latin name for the Moon, <i>Luna</i>. Philosophers <a href="/wiki/Aristotle" title="Aristotle">Aristotle</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder" title="Pliny the Elder">Pliny the Elder</a> argued that the full moon induced insanity in susceptible individuals, believing that the brain, which is mostly water, must be affected by the Moon and its power over the tides, but the Moon's gravity is too slight to affect any single person.<sup id="cite_ref-sciam_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sciam-260">[247]</a></sup> Even today, people who believe in a <a href="/wiki/Lunar_effect" title="Lunar effect">lunar effect</a> claim that admissions to psychiatric hospitals, traffic accidents, homicides or suicides increase during a full moon, but dozens of studies invalidate these claims.<sup id="cite_ref-sciam_260-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sciam-260">[247]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RottonKelly1985_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RottonKelly1985-261">[248]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MartensKelly1988_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MartensKelly1988-262">[249]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-kelly_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kelly-263">[250]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FosterRoenneberg2008_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FosterRoenneberg2008-264">[251]</a></sup></p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> 
      <div role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portal plainlist tright" style="margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em;border:solid #aaa 1px"> 
       <ul style="display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold"> 
        <li style="display:table-row"><span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Solar_system.jpg/22px-Solar_system.jpg" width="22" height="28" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Solar_system.jpg/34px-Solar_system.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Solar_system.jpg/45px-Solar_system.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4500" data-file-height="5600"></span><span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Solar_System" title="Portal:Solar System">Solar System portal</a></span></li> 
        <li style="display:table-row"><span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Moon-Mdf-2005.jpg" class="image"><img alt="icon" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Moon-Mdf-2005.jpg/28px-Moon-Mdf-2005.jpg" width="28" height="28" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Moon-Mdf-2005.jpg/42px-Moon-Mdf-2005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Moon-Mdf-2005.jpg/56px-Moon-Mdf-2005.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="1024"></a></span><span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Moon" title="Portal:Moon">Moon portal</a></span></li> 
        <li style="display:table-row"><span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Crab_Nebula.jpg/28px-Crab_Nebula.jpg" width="28" height="28" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Crab_Nebula.jpg/42px-Crab_Nebula.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Crab_Nebula.jpg/56px-Crab_Nebula.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3864" data-file-height="3864"></span><span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Astronomy" title="Portal:Astronomy">Astronomy portal</a></span></li> 
       </ul> 
      </div>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h3> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"> 
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-inclination-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-inclination_3-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Between 18.29° and 28.58° to Earth's <a href="/wiki/Equator" title="Equator">equator</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-W06_1-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-W06-1">[1]</a></sup></span></li> 
         <li id="cite_note-near-Earth_asteroids-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-near-Earth_asteroids_4-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">There are a number of <a href="/wiki/Near-Earth_asteroid" class="mw-redirect" title="Near-Earth asteroid">near-Earth asteroids</a>, including <a href="/wiki/3753_Cruithne" title="3753 Cruithne">3753 Cruithne</a>, that are <a href="/wiki/Co-orbital" class="mw-redirect" title="Co-orbital">co-orbital</a> with Earth: their orbits bring them close to Earth for periods of time but then alter in the long term (Morais et al, 2002). These are <a href="/wiki/Quasi-satellite" title="Quasi-satellite">quasi-satellites</a>&nbsp;– they are not moons as they do not orbit Earth. For more information, see <a href="/wiki/Other_moons_of_Earth" class="mw-redirect" title="Other moons of Earth">Other moons of Earth</a>.</span></li> 
         <li id="cite_note-maxval-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-maxval_10-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <i>maximum value</i> is given based on scaling of the brightness from the value of ?12.74 given for an equator to Moon-centre distance of 378&nbsp;000&nbsp;km in the NASA factsheet reference to the minimum Earth–Moon distance given there, after the latter is corrected for Earth's equatorial radius of 6&nbsp;378&nbsp;km, giving 350&nbsp;600&nbsp;km. The <i>minimum value</i> (for a distant <a href="/wiki/New_moon" title="New moon">new moon</a>) is based on a similar scaling using the maximum Earth–Moon distance of 407&nbsp;000&nbsp;km (given in the factsheet) and by calculating the brightness of the <a href="/wiki/Earthshine" class="mw-redirect" title="Earthshine">earthshine</a> onto such a new moon. The brightness of the earthshine is <span class="nowrap">[ Earth <a href="/wiki/Albedo" title="Albedo">albedo</a> ×</span> <span class="nowrap">(<a href="/wiki/Earth_radius" title="Earth radius">Earth radius</a> /</span> Radius of <a href="/wiki/Orbit_of_the_Moon" title="Orbit of the Moon">Moon's orbit</a>)<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;] relative to the direct solar illumination that occurs for a full moon. (<span class="nowrap">Earth albedo = 0.367</span>; <span class="nowrap">Earth radius = (polar</span> radius&nbsp;× equatorial <span class="nowrap">radius)<sup>½</sup> = 6 367 km</span>.)</span></li> 
         <li id="cite_note-angular_size-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-angular_size_11-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The range of angular size values given are based on simple scaling of the following values given in the fact sheet reference: at an Earth-equator to Moon-centre distance of 378&nbsp;000&nbsp;km, the <a href="/wiki/Angular_diameter" title="Angular diameter">angular size</a> is 1896&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Arcsecond" class="mw-redirect" title="Arcsecond">arcseconds</a>. The same fact sheet gives extreme Earth–Moon distances of 407&nbsp;000&nbsp;km and 357&nbsp;000&nbsp;km. For the maximum angular size, the minimum distance has to be corrected for Earth's equatorial radius of 6&nbsp;378&nbsp;km, giving 350&nbsp;600&nbsp;km.</span></li> 
         <li id="cite_note-pressure_explanation-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-pressure_explanation_14-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Lucey et al. (2006) give <span class="nowrap">10<sup>7</sup> particles cm<sup>?3</sup></span> by day and <span class="nowrap">10<sup>5</sup> particles cm<sup>?3</sup></span> by night. Along with equatorial surface temperatures of 390&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Kelvin" title="Kelvin">K</a> by day and 100&nbsp;K by night, the <a href="/wiki/Ideal_gas_law" title="Ideal gas law">ideal gas law</a> yields the pressures given in the infobox (rounded to the nearest <a href="/wiki/Order_of_magnitude" title="Order of magnitude">order of magnitude</a>): 10<sup>?7</sup>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Pascal_(unit)" title="Pascal (unit)">Pa</a> by day and 10<sup>?10</sup>&nbsp;Pa by night.</span></li> 
         <li id="cite_note-age-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-age_24-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This age is calculated from isotope dating of lunar zircons.</span></li> 
         <li id="cite_note-orbpd-124"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-orbpd_124-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">More accurately, the Moon's mean sidereal period (fixed star to fixed star) is 27.321661&nbsp;days <span class="nowrap">(27 d 07 h 43 min 11.5 s)</span>, and its mean tropical orbital period (from equinox to equinox) is 27.321582&nbsp;days <span class="nowrap">(27 d 07 h 43 min 04.7 s)</span> (<i>Explanatory Supplement to the Astronomical Ephemeris</i>, 1961, at p.107).</span></li> 
         <li id="cite_note-synpd-125"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-synpd_125-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">More accurately, the Moon's mean synodic period (between mean solar conjunctions) is 29.530589&nbsp;days <span class="nowrap">(29 d 12 h 44 min 02.9 s)</span> (<i>Explanatory Supplement to the Astronomical Ephemeris</i>, 1961, at p.107).</span></li> 
         <li id="cite_note-128"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-128">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">There is no strong correlation between the sizes of planets and the sizes of their satellites. Larger planets tend to have more satellites, both large and small, than smaller planets.</span></li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Moon_vs._Charon-129"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Moon_vs._Charon_129-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">With 27% the diameter and 60% the density of Earth, the Moon has 1.23% of the mass of Earth. The moon <a href="/wiki/Charon_(moon)" title="Charon (moon)">Charon</a> is larger relative to its primary <a href="/wiki/Pluto" title="Pluto">Pluto</a>, but Pluto is now considered to be a <a href="/wiki/Dwarf_planet" title="Dwarf planet">dwarf planet</a>.</span></li> 
         <li id="cite_note-brightness-134"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-brightness_134-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Sun's <a href="/wiki/Apparent_magnitude" title="Apparent magnitude">apparent magnitude</a> is ?26.7, while the full moon's apparent magnitude is ?12.7.</span></li> 
         <li id="cite_note-size_changes-162"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-size_changes_162-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See graph in <a href="/wiki/Sun#Life_phases" title="Sun">Sun#Life phases</a>. At present, the diameter of the Sun is increasing at a rate of about five percent per billion years. This is very similar to the rate at which the apparent angular diameter of the Moon is decreasing as it recedes from Earth.</span></li> 
         <li id="cite_note-area-166"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-area_166-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">On average, the Moon covers an area of <span class="nowrap">0.21078 square degrees</span> on the night sky.</span></li> 
        </ol> 
       </div> 
      </div>

        <li id="cite_note-Vasavada1999-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Vasavada1999_12-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">A.R. Vasavada; D.A. Paige &amp; S.E. Wood (1999). "Near-Surface Temperatures on Mercury and the Moon and the Stability of Polar Ice Deposits". <i><a href="/wiki/Icarus_(journal)" title="Icarus (journal)">Icarus</a></i>. <b>141</b> (2): 179–193. <a href="/wiki/Bibcode" title="Bibcode">Bibcode</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1999Icar..141..179V">1999Icar..141..179V</a>. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1006%2Ficar.1999.6175">10.1006/icar.1999.6175</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Icarus&amp;rft.atitle=Near-Surface+Temperatures+on+Mercury+and+the+Moon+and+the+Stability+of+Polar+Ice+Deposits&amp;rft.volume=141&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=179-193&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1006%2Ficar.1999.6175&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F1999Icar..141..179V&amp;rft.au=A.R.+Vasavada&amp;rft.au=D.A.+Paige&amp;rft.au=S.E.+Wood&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMoon" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></span></li> 
        <li id="cite_note-L06-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-L06_13-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-L06_13-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-L06_13-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Lucey, Paul; Korotev, Randy L.; et al. (2006).         <li id="cite_note-Berardelli-69"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Berardelli_69-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Berardelli_69-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Phil Berardelli (9 November 2006). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://news.sciencemag.org/2006/11/long-live-moon">"Long Live the Moon!"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Science_(journal)" title="Science (journal)">Science</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20141018153016/http://news.sciencemag.org/2006/11/long-live-moon">Archived</a> from the original on 18 October 2014.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Long+Live+the+Moon%21&amp;rft.pub=Science&amp;rft.date=2006-11-09&amp;rft.au=Phil+Berardelli&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.sciencemag.org%2F2006%2F11%2Flong-live-moon&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMoon" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></span></li>

(18 June 2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v522/n7556/full/nature14479.html">"A permanent, asymmetric dust cloud around the Moon"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Nature_(journal)" title="Nature (journal)">Nature</a></i>. <b>522</b> (7556): 324–326. <a href="/wiki/Bibcode" title="Bibcode">Bibcode</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2015Natur.522..324H">2015Natur.522..324H</a>. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1038%2Fnature14479">10.1038/nature14479</a>. <a href="/wiki/PubMed_Identifier" class="mw-redirect" title="PubMed Identifier">PMID</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26085272">26085272</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Nature&amp;rft.atitle=A+permanent%2C+asymmetric+dust+cloud+around+the+Moon&amp;rft.volume=522&amp;rft.issue=7556&amp;rft.pages=324-326&amp;rft.date=2015-06-18&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F26085272&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1038%2Fnature14479&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F2015Natur.522..324H&amp;rft.aulast=Hor%C3%A1nyi&amp;rft.aufirst=M.&amp;rft.au=Szalay%2C+J.+R.&amp;rft.au=Kempf%2C+S.&amp;rft.au=Schmidt%2C+J.&amp;rft.au=Gr%C3%BCn%2C+E.&amp;rft.au=Srama%2C+R.&amp;rft.au=Sternovsky%2C+Z.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nature.com%2Fnature%2Fjournal%2Fv522%2Fn7556%2Ffull%2Fnature14479.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMoon" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></span></li>

(1992). <i>Solar system evolution</i>. <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press" title="Cambridge University Press">Cambridge University Press</a>. p.&nbsp;307. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-521-37212-7" title="Special:BookSources/0-521-37212-7">0-521-37212-7</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Solar+system+evolution&amp;rft.pages=307&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1992&amp;rft.isbn=0-521-37212-7&amp;rft.aulast=Taylor&amp;rft.aufirst=S.R.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMoon" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></li> 
        <li><cite class="citation web">Teague, K. (2006). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.apolloarchive.com/apollo_archive.html">"The Project Apollo Archive"</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">12 April</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+Project+Apollo+Archive&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.aulast=Teague&amp;rft.aufirst=K.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.apolloarchive.com%2Fapollo_archive.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMoon" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></li> 
        <li><cite class="citation journal">Wilhelms, D.E. (1987). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://ser.sese.asu.edu/GHM/">"Geologic History of the Moon"</a>. <i>U.S. Geological Survey Professional paper</i>. <b>1348</b><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">12 April</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=U.S.+Geological+Survey+Professional+paper&amp;rft.atitle=Geologic+History+of+the+Moon&amp;rft.volume=1348&amp;rft.date=1987&amp;rft.aulast=Wilhelms&amp;rft.aufirst=D.E.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fser.sese.asu.edu%2FGHM%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMoon" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></li> 
        <li><cite class="citation book">Wilhelms, D.E. (1993). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.lpi.usra.edu/publications/books/rockyMoon/"><i>To a Rocky Moon: A Geologist's History of Lunar Exploration</i></a>. Tucson, Arizona: <a href="/wiki/University_of_Arizona_Press" title="University of Arizona Press">University of Arizona Press</a>. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-8165-1065-2" title="Special:BookSources/0-8165-1065-2">0-8165-1065-2</a><span class="reference-accessdate">.        </ul> 
      </div>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cartographic_resources">Cartographic resources</span></h3> 
      <ul> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.google.com/maps/space/moon/@6.1467095,139.2754359,23010541m/data=!3m1!1e3">The Moon on Google Maps</a>, a 3-D rendition of the moon akin to Google Earth</li> 
       <li><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.lpi.usra.edu/resources/cla/">"Consolidated Lunar Atlas"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Lunar_and_Planetary_Institute" title="Lunar and Planetary Institute">Lunar and Planetary Institute</a><span class="reference-accessdate">.       <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Observation_tools">Observation tools</span></h3> 
      <ul> 
       <li><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070820075142/http://sunearth.gsfc.nasa.gov/eclipse/SKYCAL/SKYCAL.html">"NASA's SKYCAL—Sky Events Calendar"</a>. <a href="/wiki/NASA" title="NASA">NASA</a>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://sunearth.gsfc.nasa.gov/eclipse/SKYCAL/SKYCAL.html">the original</a> on 20 August 2007<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">27 August</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=NASA%27s+SKYCAL%E2%80%94Sky+Events+Calendar&amp;rft.pub=NASA&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fsunearth.gsfc.nasa.gov%2Feclipse%2FSKYCAL%2FSKYCAL.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMoon" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></li> 
       <li><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/moonrise.html">"Find moonrise, moonset and moonphase for a location"</a>. 2008<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 February</span> 2008</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Find+moonrise%2C+moonset+and+moonphase+for+a+location&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.timeanddate.com%2Fworldclock%2Fmoonrise.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMoon" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span></li> 
       <li><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.crescentmoonwatch.org/nextnewmoon.htm">"HMNAO's Moon Watch"</a>. 2005<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">24 May</span> 2009</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=HMNAO%27s+Moon+Watch&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.crescentmoonwatch.org%2Fnextnewmoon.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMoon" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&nbsp;</span></span> See when the next new crescent moon is visible for any location.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="General">General</span></h3> 
      <ul> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.esa.int/var/esa/storage/images/esa_multimedia/images/2013/01/lunar_base_made_with_3d_printing/12501019-1-eng-GB/Lunar_base_made_with_3D_printing.jpg">Lunar shelter</a> (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Technology/Building_a_lunar_base_with_3D_printing">building a lunar base with 3D printing</a>)</li> 
      </ul>

             <li><a href="/wiki/Etymology_of_the_word_%22Earth%22" class="mw-redirect" title="Etymology of the word &quot;Earth&quot;">Etymology of the word "Earth"</a></li> 
             <li><a href="/wiki/History_of_the_world" title="History of the world">History of the world</a></li> 
             <li><a href="/wiki/International_law" title="International law">International law</a></li> 
             <li><a href="/wiki/Landscape_painting" title="Landscape painting">Landscape painting</a></li> 
             <li><a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states" title="List of sovereign states">List of countries</a></li> 
             <li><a href="/wiki/World_economy" title="World economy">World economy</a></li> 
            </ul> 
           </div> </td> 
         </tr>

         <tr> 
          <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="text-align:center;;width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Planet" title="Planet">Planets</a></th> 
          <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"> 
           <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
            <ul> 
             <li><a href="/wiki/Terrestrial_planet" title="Terrestrial planet">Terrestrial planets</a>

          <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Help:Authority_control" title="Help:Authority control">Authority control</a></th> 
          <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"> 
           <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
            <ul> 
             <li><span class="nowrap"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/identities/containsVIAFID/311490648">WorldCat Identities</a></span></li>

             <li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Library_of_Congress_Control_Number" title="Library of Congress Control Number">LCCN</a>: <span class="uid"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://id.loc.gov/authorities/subjects/sh85087107">sh85087107</a></span></span></li> 
             <li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Integrated_Authority_File" title="Integrated Authority File">GND</a>: <span class="uid"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://d-nb.info/gnd/1085673251">1085673251</a></span></span></li> 
             <li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Syst%C3%A8me_universitaire_de_documentation" title="Système universitaire de documentation">SUDOC</a>: <span class="uid"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.idref.fr/027282414">027282414</a></span></span></li> 
             <li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Biblioth%C3%A8que_nationale_de_France" title="Bibliothèque nationale de France">BNF</a>: <span class="uid"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://catalogue.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/cb119358377">cb119358377</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://data.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/cb119358377">(data)</a></span></span></li> 
             <li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/National_Diet_Library" title="National Diet Library">NDL</a>: <span class="uid"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://id.ndl.go.jp/auth/ndlna/00573509">00573509</a></span></span></li>

             <li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Biblioteca_Nacional_de_Espa%C3%B1a" title="Biblioteca Nacional de España">BNE</a>: <span class="uid"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://catalogo.bne.es/uhtbin/authoritybrowse.cgi?action=display&amp;authority_id=XX456648">XX456648</a></span></span></li> 
            </ul> 
           </div> </td>
